questions.text:
Match the following:
Column I Column II
1 Facial nerve A Shrugging of shoulder
2 Spinal accessory nerve B Taste from anterior two third of the tongue
3 Glossopharyngeal nerve C Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4 Mandibular nerve D Chewing
questions.solution:
Correct answer option 1:- 1-B,2-A,3-C,4-D


The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes retraction of scapula, shrugging of the shoulder and overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior). Paralysis of trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula at rest. 
The glossopharyngeal nerve carries taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. The mandibular nerve (V3) is responsible for chewing movements as it gives motor supply to muscles of mastication. It contains both sensory and motor fibers. The facial nerve (CN VII) controls facial expression muscles and provides taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. 


Tongue nerve supply 

 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 232,501,502,810 .

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the third section of the vertebral artery?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- option  3. D 
Vertebral artery is one of the principal arteries that supply the brain. It is the first and largest branch of the first part of Subclavian Artery.It has four parts—
1st part- Cervical Part
2nd part- Vertebral Part 
3rd part- Suboccipital Part 
4th part- Intracranial Part

The 3rd part of vertebral artery moves from foramen transversarium to foramen magnum reaching the posterior arch of the vertebra.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 418,589,590,827,828,1464.e84

questions.text: Identify the highlighted nerve in the given cranial cavity section.
questions.solution:
Correct answer, option 1. Oculomotor nerve. 

The marked nerve in the given base of skull image is Oculomotor nerve, which is exiting skull by Superior orbital fissure. Since it's just below the optic nerve, it further confirms the diagnosis. 




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 391,563,566

questions.text: Which nerves are responsible for innervating the external anal sphincter, contributing to voluntary control of defecation and anal continence? Choose the correct answer from the following options regarding the spinal segments involved in this innervation:
questions.solution:
Correct answer option 1. S3, S4, S5.
External anal sphincter is innervated by inferior rectal branch of pudendal nerve (anterior divisions of S2, S3, S4 sacral spinal nerves) mainly and by perineal branch of S4. Pudendal nerve is the main sensory motor nerve of the perineum and sensory nerve of the genitalia.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e42,1201

questions.text: Which structure plays a key role in providing stability during shoulder movements, preventing dislocations, and ensuring smooth function? Choose the correct answer from the following options:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Rotator cuff. 
'Dynamic stabilizer of shoulder joint’ is used for rotator cuff or musculotendinous cuff. The tendons of the subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor muscles that are united to the underlying capsule of the shoulder joint are referred to as the rotator cuff. The cuff is crucial in maintaining the stability of the shoulder joint.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 813,785.e1

questions.text: Which of the following structures contribute to the formation of the medial lemniscus, a major sensory pathway that transmits fine touch, vibration, and proprioceptive information to the brain? Choose the correct answer from the following options related to its components:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1.
Medial lemniscus is formed from Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 388

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply blood to the medulla?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 4. Superior Cerebellar artery




Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/medulla-oblongata

questions.text: A patient presents with sensory loss in the thumb and index finger. Which nerve roots are most likely responsible for innervating these dermatomes? Select the correct answer from the following options:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. C6 C7. 
The thumb and index finger dermatomes are supplied by the C6 and C7 nerve roots , respectively. The dermatomes are the areas of skin innervated by the various spinal nerve roots. The C6 nerve root innervates the thumb, while the C7 nerve root innervates the index finger. C8 supplies ring finger and little finger. The C5, C6, C7, and C8 nerve roots supply the muscles of the hand and wrist, and they are responsible for sensation in the corresponding dermatomes.




 

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 13th edition Page no 1445

questions.text: A patient presents with suspected weakness in hand muscles. Which of the following muscles is assessed using the card test to evaluate its function? Select the correct answer from the following options:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Palmar interossei
A card test is performed for the palmar interossei muscles. This test assesses the function of these muscles, which are responsible for adducting the fingers towards the middle finger. To perform the card test, a small card or piece of paper is placed between the patient's fingers, and they are asked to hold it tightly. If the card can be pulled out easily, it indicates weakness in the palmar interossei muscles.


 

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page no 67,68.

questions.text: A patient presents with difficulty performing overhead arm abduction. Which of the following muscles is not involved in this movement?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 4. Pectoralis Major
The muscles which help in  abduction of arm are :-
0-15 : Supraspinatus ( Supplied by Suprascapular nerve )
15-90 : Lateral fibers of Deltoid ( Supplied by axillary nerve )
> 90 : Trapezius & Serratus anterior ( 11th Cranial Nerve )

Pectoralis Major is supplied by medial and lateral pectoral nerves. Its actions are adduction, flexion and internal rotation. 



Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 786e.1, 813, 815 e.1, 816 e.1

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the index finger
Loss of sensation of the little finger

questions.text: Marked structure's lesion leads to which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct answer, option 1
Median Nerve is the region that is marked. Sensory loss on the lateral 3½ of the palmar region and the corresponding nail bed might result from injury to the median nerve. Along with sensory loss median nerve lesion causes thenar muscles atrophy resulting in Ape Thumb deformity. 
Hypothenar muscle atrophy, loss of sensation of the little finger and palmaris brevis dysfunction is seen in Ulnar nerve lesion.





Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition Page no 951,952,953

questions.text: In a patient with damage to the mammillary bodies, which of the following structures do the fibers from the mammillary body project to? Select the correct answer from the following options:
questions.solution:
Mammillary bodies are a pair of small round bodies which are a part of the diencephalon and forms a part of limbic system, located at the anterior end of the fornix. They are important for processing of memories. Projection axons from two major fibre tracts: a descending mammilotegmental tract terminate in the tegmental nuclei of Gudden and ascending mammilothalamic tract terminates in the anterior complex of the thalamus.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 523,524

questions.text: A patient presents with severe gastrointestinal bleeding. Which of the following arteries is the most vital source of blood supply to the stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Left Gastric artery
Most important blood supply to the stomach is the left gastric artery.The left gastric artery is the branch of the celiac axis and is the largest artery supplying the stomach.

Blood Supply of Stomach:

  • Left gastric artery: Branch of celiac trunk (Largest) 
  • Right gastric artery: Branch of hepatic artery
  • Right gastroepiploic artery: Branch of gastroduodenal artery 
  • Left gastroepiploic artery: Branch of splenic artery
  • Short gastric arteries: Branch of splenic artery




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1164,1165

questions.text: In Anatomy exam, professor points out to Facial colliculus in a brainstem specimen. Pick the nerve nucleus that underlies the facial colliculus.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Abducens
The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the 4th ventricle. It's formed by the looping of facial fibers over the abducens nerve nucleus. Hence, the Facial colliculus overlies the abducens nucleus.

   



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e17,410

questions.text: Which joints' axes move parallel to one another as the foot pronates?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1
The talonavicular joint (present along the longitudinal axis) and the calcaneocuboid joint make up the midtarsal joint (present along the oblique axis).These two axes are comparatively divergent when the subtalar joint is in a neutral position. However, these two axes become parallel as the subtalar joint pronates, i.e. during the unlocking of the foot.




Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no  1445-1450

questions.text:
Based on the conductance graph of a neuron presented below, name the ions:


1. Na+ , K+ 
2. K+, Na+ 
3. Na+ , Ca2+ 
4. Ca2+ , Na+
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option1. Na+ , K+ 
A- Na+
B- K+ 

Na + channels have the ability to open and close rapidly, which facilitates the depolarization phase of action potentials. On the other hand, K+ channels are responsible for initiating the repolarization phase during action potentials as shown in the image below. 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 88

questions.text: A patient presents with an abnormal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform. Which of the following events causes the c wave in JVP, typically observed as a small upward deflection during the early phase of ventricular contraction? Select the correct answer from the following options:
questions.solution:
Jugular venous pressure is the indirectly observed pulse pressure over the venous system via visualisation of the internal jugular vein. 
JVP waveforms: 




Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: A patient presents with malabsorption symptoms. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the transfer of glucose across the intestinal epithelium? Select the correct answer from the following options:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 2. Secondary active transport . It is the method of transport of glucose in the intestine. Cells can take up glucose either through facilitated diffusion or, in the kidneys and gut, through a secondary active transport with Na.
GLUT receptors mediate facilitated diffusion.
SGLT 1- Kidney, GIT
SGLT 2- Kidney
You can remember SGLTs by keeping in mind we have only 1 Gut whereas 2 Kidneys. 



Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 52

questions.text: Which hormones fall under the hypothalamus's inhibitory control?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 4. Both growth hormone and prolactin. 
Both growth hormone and prolactin are under inhibitory control of hypothalamus. Growth hormone release is regulated by the hypothalamus, which also secretes somatostatin, an inhibitor of growth hormone release, as well as growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH). Prolactin is inhibited by dopamine, which is secreted by the hypothalamus.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition Page no 908, 917

questions.text: A patient developed sudden decrease in heart rate following CO2 inflation during Laparoscopic Surgery. Which of the following is the possible mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 2. Peritoneal stretching.
The sudden decrease in heart rate, known as bradycardia, is commonly associated with peritoneal stretching during CO2 insufflation. The stretching stimulates the vagus nerve, leading to a reflex response that causes bradycardia. 


Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No: 164.

questions.text: Second messengers play a crucial role in the intracellular signaling cascade, helping to amplify the signals from extracellular stimuli such as hormones or neurotransmitters. Among the following molecules, which is not considered a second messenger in signal transduction pathways?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3. Guanylyl cyclase. Second messengers are intracellular molecules that transmit signals from extracellular receptors to target molecules within the cell. cAMP and IP3 are classic second messengers involved in various signaling pathways, such as G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) pathways. DAG is another important second messenger, often working in tandem with IP3. Guanylyl cyclase, however, is an enzyme that catalyzes the production of another second messenger (cGMP), not a second messenger itself.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 139

questions.text: Which are the adrenergic beta-receptors that have the ability to cause lipolysis in fat cells?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 4. Beta-3
The adrenergic receptor that primarily mediates lipolysis (breakdown of fat) in fat cells is the beta-3 adrenergic receptor .Activation of β3 receptors leads to an increase in the intracellular levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), which in turn activates hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for catalyzing the breakdown of triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, which are released into the bloodstream.




Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 256

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain is undergoing Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS) therapy as part of their pain management plan. TENS is thought to provide pain relief through various physiological mechanisms. Which of the following mechanisms best explains how TENS works to alleviate pain?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3. Gating at the spinal cord
According to the gate control theory of pain, TENS works by stimulating large A-beta fibers that transmit non-painful sensations (such as touch). These fibers "compete" with pain signals carried by smaller A-delta and C fibers. The stimulation of the larger fibers at the spinal cord level helps "close the gate" to pain signals, thus reducing the perception of pain. This mechanism primarily occurs at the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 169

questions.text: A patient is suffering from gallstone-caused obstruction  jaundice. What will be the urobilinogen level?
questions.solution:
Correct answer 4. Completely absent.
Urobilinogen is derived from conjugated bilirubin by gut bacteria. In obstructive jaundice, since no conjugated bilirubin can reach the gut due to obstruction, hence urobilinogen will be absent.


Reference :https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539698/

questions.text: Which of the following types of motor neurons innervates the intrafusal muscle fibers, which are responsible for detecting changes in muscle length and contributing to muscle spindle function?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 2. 
Intrafusal muscle fibers are innervated by Gamma Motor neurons.
Alpha motor fibers- Extrafusal muscle fibers
Beta fibers-Touch and pressure
Delta fibers- Pain and temperature



Reference: Diwan FH, Ito F. Intrafusal muscle fibre types in frog spindles. J Anat. 1989 Apr;163:191-200. PMID: 2532636; PMCID: PMC1256529.

questions.text: Genetic alterations that do not change the DNA's sequence are referred to as epigenetic changes. The following can all identify epigenetic change, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
HPLC is used in the determination of plasma levels of drugs/metabolites. 
Its also used to separate, identify, and quantify each part of a mixture.
It's not used to identify epigenetic changes.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: What is the objective of a real-time polymerase chain reaction?
questions.solution:
Real time polymerase chain reaction is done for monitoring amplification of target nucleic acid. A quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), also known as real-time polymerase chain reaction, is a molecular biology laboratory technique that uses the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify and simultaneously quantify the targeted DNA molecule. Real Time PCR can detect both DNA and RNA but unlike traditional PCR, it's main aim is quantitative assessment of target nucleic acid. Hence, option 4. is the best possible answer among the given options. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies causes a THF deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 2. Vit B12



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 538.

questions.text: In metabolism, anaplerotic reactions play a crucial role in replenishing intermediates of the citric acid cycle (TCA cycle). These reactions are essential for maintaining metabolic flux and ensuring the proper functioning of cellular processes. Which of the following reactions is an example of an anaplerotic reaction that helps replenish intermediates of the citric acid cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pyruvate to oxaloacetate
Anaplerotic reactions are chemical reactions which help in formation of intermediates of a metabolic pathway. Conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase. This reaction maintains adequate amount of oxaloacetate which then condenses with acetyl co-A to form citrate which is the first step of Kreb’s cycle.

Anaplerotic reactions of TCA. 


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 153.

questions.text: CG islands are regions of the DNA that are rich in cytosine (C) and guanine (G) dinucleotides, often located near the promoter regions of genes. These regions play a significant role in regulating gene expression and maintaining cellular functions. Which of the following processes is most closely associated with the importance of CG islands in our DNA?
questions.solution:
The cytosine nucleotide is followed by a guanine nucleotide at the CpG sites, also known as CG sites, in a linear sequence along the 5' 3' orientation of the DNA molecule. CpG islands are genomic areas having a high frequency of CpG sites. CpG dinucleotides' cytosines can be methylated to create 5-methylcytosines. A gene's expression can be altered by this methylation. Methylation results in silencing/decreasing the expression of the gene. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with signs of cognitive impairment. Upon investigation, it is found that the patient has elevated levels of a specific amino acid, which is associated with an increased risk of cognitive decline in aging individuals. Which of the following elevated levels is most commonly linked to cognitive impairment in older adults?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Homocysteine. 

With ageing, a slight decrease in cognitive impairment is seen due to increase in level of homocysteine.
Features associated with congnitive impairment (dementia) in the elderly are: high level of plasma homocysteine and low level of plasma folate and vitamin B12. 



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 375.

questions.text: 2,3-BPG binds to _________________ site of hemoglobin and __________________ the affinity for oxygen
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 2. beta; decreases.
 

2,3-BPG (2,3-bisphosphoglycerate) binds to the beta subunits of hemoglobin. This binding decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, promoting the release of oxygen in tissues where it is needed.
The presence of 2,3-BPG stabilizes the T (tense) state of hemoglobin, which has a lower affinity for oxygen compared to the R (relaxed) state.
Thus, 2,3-BPG binding to the beta subunits of hemoglobin reduces its affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen delivery to tissues.
 



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 53.

questions.text: Photosensitivity is a symptom of Porphyria. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies leading to Porphyria does not have photosensitivity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option 2. ALA dehydratase

Porphyria is a group of disorders caused by deficiencies in enzymes involved in the heme biosynthesis pathway. The symptoms can vary depending on the specific enzyme deficiency. Photosensitivity is a common symptom in several types of porphyria due to the accumulation of porphyrins or porphyrin precursors, which are sensitive to light.
However in ALA dehydratase deficiency, ALA is accumulated which doesn't absorb light and cause photosensitivity.
Note: ALA dehydratase is typically inhibited by Lead. 
 





Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 310.

choices.text: It can be reduced from multiple branches/end
It can be stored at multiple sites
It can provide glucose as much as needed and when needed for 1 week

questions.text: In the body, glucose is stored in the form of glycogen rather than as free glucose. This storage form has several advantages, especially in terms of efficient utilization and availability. Which of the following reasons best explains why glucose is stored in the form of glycogen?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1. It is compact. 
Glucose is stored in Glycogen form because it is compact. 
Because glycogen is so heavily branched, body is able to pack more glucose units together in a small space, hence being more compact and having a greater solubility.

Other options
  • Option 2 - True - but not the main reason for storage of glucose as glycogen. 
  • Option 3 - Glycogen is only stored in muscles and liver, not multiple sites.
  • Option 4 - Liver glycogen provides glucose for 12-18 hours of fasting, not 1 week. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 152.

questions.text: A teenager has intermittent, severe stomach discomfort and tingling in her limbs. She has a history of exposure to paint from freshly constructed homes. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. ALA dehydratase. 

The above clinical scenario(with exposure to paint) and pain abdomen/neuropathy(tingling) and abdominal colic(pain) suggests Lead poisoning.  Lead interacts with ALA dehydratase and ferrochelatase(in the heme synthesis pathway) leading to its inhibition. 


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 310.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with chief complaints of severe pain in abdomen. He has multiple xanthomas on physical examination. A blood sample was drawn for testing, and the plasma in the sample appeared milky. Which lipoprotein is increased, out of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3. Chylomicron.

The symptoms in the question stem(milky plasma/xanthomas/ pain abdomen - likely pancreatitis secondary to high cholesterol levels) are characteristic of Familial Hyperchylomicronemia. Lipoprotein Lipase enzyme is deficient.  There will be increase in chylomicron and chylomicron remnants in the body but more prominent will be chylomicron. (option 3 > option 4). Chylomicrons in the blood cause milky plasma and xanthomas. 

Other options
  • Option 1 (LDL) - Not associated with a milky plasma appearance or abdominal pain. Typically linked to cardiovascular disease but not in this scenario.
  • Option 2(HDL) - Not related to milky plasma or abdominal pain. HDL is involved in reverse cholesterol transport and doesn’t cause xanthomas or a milky plasma.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 268.

questions.text: A toddler who accidentally ingested cyanide is sent to the hospital. It prevents the citric acid cycle function by preventing formation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3. NAD+ 
Cyanide blocks Complex IV (Cytochrome oxidase) of Electron transport Chain. It has no direct effect on any component of Citric acid cycle. If the electron transport chain is blocked, then the electron carriers NADH and FADH cannot unload their electrons into it, which means NAD+ and FAD+ are not regenerated. Since Glycolysis and the Krebs cycle both require NAD+ (and the Krebs cycle requires FAD), NAD+ will get depleted and NADH level is raised, both of these processes will stop running.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: In a 40 year old patient you see swelling in the angle of the mouth with ear lobule being elevated. You suspect it to be a parotid tumor. Which is the most common parotid gland tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pleomorphic adenoma
 
PLEOMORPHIC ADENOMA
 
  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor (~60% of all parotid tumors). It can develop from the submandibular, parotid, or other small salivary glands. It typically comes from the parotid's tail. Pleomorphic adenomas are slow-growing tumors that might become fairly large. 
  • They typically occur in females of the third or fourth decade.
  • Because both epithelial and mesenchymal components can be observed in histology, they are known as "mixed tumors." 
  • The tumor's stroma can vary in type—it could be mucoid, fibroid, vascular, myxochondroid, or chondroid—and its epithelial proportion may vary.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

choices.text: Can be used during sentinel lymph node biopsy
Helps to check for negative tumor margins

questions.text: A doctor after Hemithyroidectomy of a patient in OT, sends a specimen for Frozen section. Which of the following is incorrect about frozen sections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is - Option 3 -  Provides definitive diagnosis in all cancers

This statement is incorrect. Frozen sections provide a rapid diagnosis, but they may not always be definitive, especially in complex or rare cancers. Final diagnosis is usually confirmed with permanent sectioning and further analysis. Other options are correct statements. 

Other options

  • Option 1 - Correct - Frozen sections can be used to identify metastasis, especially during procedures like lymph node sampling.
  • Option 2 -  Correct: Frozen section is commonly used during sentinel lymph node biopsy to check for metastasis in real-time.
  • Option 4 - Correct: Frozen sections are often used during surgery to check for clear margins, ensuring that the tumor has been completely excised.
 

[Extra Edge]: Frozen section in Diagnostic Pathology

  • It is a pathological laboratory procedure done to perform rapid microscopic analysis of a specimen. Mainly used in oncological surgery. 
  • It can be used for diagnosis in many cases, but quality of slides produced is lower compared to formalin fixed paraffin embedded tissue processing (gives more accurate diagnosis).
  • Uses include Intraoperative assessment of resected specimens to check whether resection margins are clear of the tumor.
  • Another use is Sentinel lymph node biopsy to check for presence of tumor in dissected lymph nodes, to check for suspected metastasis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 275.

questions.text: Apoptosis is defined as a form of programmed cell death that occurs in a controlled, energy-dependent manner, where cells actively participate in their own death to maintain normal tissue homeostasis without triggering inflammation. Pick the option that induces apoptosis in a cell.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glucocorticoids
  • Glucocorticoids are potent inducers of apoptosis in many cell types. In glucocorticoid sensitive cells, apoptosis and other cellular effects are induced through activating the glucocorticoid receptor (GR). 
  • Glucocorticoids are known to induce apoptosis of lymphocytes and lymphoblasts - hence, in treatment regimens of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemias (ALL) - Steroids play a major role.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids) also have well-documented anti inflammatory effects, and their administration may result in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 108.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient from India presents with lymphadenopathy, fever, and weight loss. A biopsy of the lymph node reveals features consistent with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Based on the typical patterns of lymphoma subtypes in India, which of the following is the most common subtype of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in this region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
The most common subtype of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in India is diffuse large B cell lymphoma.

[Extra Edge] NHL types

B-Cell
1. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: MC subtype (34%)
2. Follicular Centre-cell lymphomas: 12.6%
3. B-cell small lymphocytic lymphoma: 5.7%
4. Mantle-cell lymphoma: 3.4%
5. Marginal zone B-cell lymphomas (including MALT lymphomas): 8.2%
6. Burkitt's lymphoma- 1-5% 

T-Cell
1. T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma: 6%
2. Anaplastic large-cell lymphomas of T/null-cell type- 3.4%
3. Other nodal peripheral T-cell lymphomas: 2.9%

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 600.

choices.text: Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°c with a shelf life of 6 month
Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°c with a self life of 5 days
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: option 2. 

Platelets can be stored at temperatures between 20°C and 24°C, with a shelf life of 5 days. These platelet concentrates are used to treat conditions like thrombocytopenia, platelet function defects, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and to prevent dilutional thrombocytopenia during massive blood transfusions or in cases of bone marrow failure. Agitation during storage is crucial for maintaining the viability and function of platelets, as they continue to metabolize glucose and produce lactate at room temperature. Agitation ensures even distribution, prevents clumping, and facilitates gas exchange.

Other options

Option (1) and (4)
Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate are typically stored at –30°C. Before use, they are thawed at temperatures between 30°C and 37°C in the blood bank, then transported at ambient temperature to the ward. They must be used immediately after thawing and should not be refrozen. FFP can be stored for 1 year and cryoprecipitate for 2 years. 

Option (3)
Whole blood and packed red cells are stored between 2°C and 6°C, and transported between 2°C and 10°C. Packed red cells stored with SAGM (sodium, adenine, glucose, and mannitol) have a shelf life of up to 42 days.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 886,890.

questions.text: 85-year-old man was involved in a car accident and visited the hospital. He sustained multiple lower-limb fractures, rib fractures, and lung contusions. He eventually passed away from his wounds. An autopsy lung biopsy revealed the following characteristics. What is the most probable reason for his demise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Fat embolism

  • Fat embolism is the most probable reason for his demise.
  • The patient has a history of a traffic accident with a lower limb fracture, which results in fat embolism since lengthy bone fractures cause microscopic fat globules to leak.
  • The small pulmonary artery branch in this region of the lung has distinct, circular holes (fat globules) that are typical of a fat embolism.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 131.

questions.text:
6-year-old child who is pallorous has previously recieved two blood transfusions. Fever and petechial haemorrhages have also appeared in him.His Hb is 9 gm/dL, platelet count is 20,000/mm3 and 60,000/mm3, respectively. The results of flow cytometry show blasts that are
CD-10 +ve, CD-19 +ve, CD-33 + ve, CD-117 +ve, MPO +ve and CD-3 -ve. The diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Mixed phenotypic acute leukemia
 
  • The most likely diagnosis is mixed phenotypic acute leukemia.
  • Mixed-phenotype acute leukemia (MPAL) is a rare but difficult-to-treat hematologic malignancy with immunophenotypic co-expression of at least two cell lineages, or with only rare cases involving all three lineages, e.g. myeloid with B- or T-lymphoid or all three of myeloid, B- and T-lymphoid altogether
  • In the given case scenario - CD10 and CD19 are B-lymphoid markers whereas CD33/CD117 and Myeloperoxidase are myeloid lineage markers and hence, the child likely has MPAL (Mixed Phenotypic Acute leukemia) 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 809.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department complaining of neck swelling. Cervical lymphadenopathy was discovered during the examination. Following a lymph node biopsy, HPE revealed the image below. Identify the cancer and the characteristic feature.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hodgkin’s with R-S cells; EBV infection

  • The given image shows Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) which are considered pathognomic/typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • They are distinct neoplastic giant cells (30-60 um in size) with abundant cytoplasm, 2 large nuclei, and 2 large inclusion like nucleoli giving an Owl Eye appearance that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers. Reed Sternberg cells in a background of inflammatory cells infiltrate are diagnostic of Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin's Lymphoma is typically associated with EBV infection.  


Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) variants



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

choices.text: Components of complement can assist in chemotaxis

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding cellular events in acute inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) PECAM/CD31 is responsible for neutrophil activation
 
  • PECAM-1, platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 also called CD31, a cellular adhesion molecule expressed on leukocytes and endothelial cells, mediates the binding events needed for leukocytes to traverse the endothelium(Diapedesis). PECAM is involved in transmigration and not activation. Hence option 1 is incorrect. 
  • The initial rolling interactions are mediated by selectins, of which there are three types: one expressed on leukocytes (L-selectin), one on endothelium (E-selectin), and one in platelets and on endothelium (P-selectin)
  • TNF and IL-1 induce endothelial expression of ligands for integrins, mainly vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 (VCAM-1), the ligand for the β1 integrin VLA-4, and intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1), the ligand for the β2 integrins LFA-1 and MAC-1, which causes adhesion of neutrophils. 






Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 79.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and jaundice. Laboratory tests reveal a positive Direct Coombs test. The patient has a history of recent blood transfusion. In which of the following conditions would the Direct Coombs test NOT be positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Aplastic anemia
Direct coomb’s test is positive in all of these conditions except Aplastic anaemia. The direct Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that are stuck to the surface of red blood cells. It is used for the diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Thus direct coombs test is positive hemolytic anemia of transfusion, AIHA and hemorrhagic disease of newborn. 


Fig: Direct Coombs Test

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) following a severe bacterial pneumonia. Chest imaging reveals bilateral infiltrates, and oxygenation is impaired. Based on the pathophysiology of ARDS, which of the following is the primary cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is Option (4) Damage to Endothelial cells > Option(2) - Answer confirmed by consulting with SRs/Assistant Professor at AIIMS, Delhi. 

ARDS is a progressive condition that includes three stages:
1. Exudative
2. Proliferative
3. Fibrotic.

The exudative stage involves injury to the alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type II pneumocytes(endothelial-epithelial barrier damage) While the initial insult damages both endothelial cells and type II pneumocytes - the primary inciting event is the damage to endothelial cells which results in the secretion of multiple inflammatory cytokines(TNF-alpha/IL-1/IL-8) that cause Neutrophil activation and migration - causing further endothelial-epithelial damage - causes fluid accumulation leading to non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema which is characteristic of ARDS. The endothelial injury also leads to microthrombi and results in ischemic injury too.

The proliferative stage involves the proliferation of type II pneumocytes and the synthesis of new pulmonary surfactant. (Hence, option 1 is incorrect - there is proliferation of type 2 pneumocytes)

In the fibrotic phase, the alveolar edema and inflammatory exudates are converted to extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis, necessitating long-term support with mechanical ventilation and/or supplemental oxygen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 676.

questions.text: A patient with yellowish discoloration of conjunctiva presents in OPD. Urine urobilinogen was found to be negative. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Obstructive jaundice
In obstructive jaundice, urobilinogen levels are typically decreased or absent in urine. This occurs because the obstruction prevents conjugated bilirubin from entering the intestines, where it would normally be converted to urobilinogen by gut bacteria and then excreted in urine.  
 

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2650.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and a history of persistent diarrhea. Genetic testing reveals abnormalities in genes responsible for immune system function. Based on the common genetic causes of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), which of the following genes is not typically involved in SCID?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) BTK

BTK (Bruton tyrosine kinase) mutation is seen in Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

* [Extra Edge]: SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency)
Both humoral and cell-mediated immunity are defective in SCID
  • X LINKED SCID
Most common and results from a mutation in the gamma chain subunit of cytokine receptors.
This protein is a signal-transducing component of the receptors for IL2, IL4, IL7, IL9, IL11, IL15, and IL 21
  • AUTOSOMAL RECESSIVE SCID
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is the primary cause of AR SCID.
  • Other Causes
  • Recombinase activating gene mutation (RAG)
  • JAK3 intracellular kinase mutation: Important for signal transmission via the cytokine receptor gamma chain.
Remember IL7 Receptor is most commonly mutated in SCID if nothing else is mentioned in the question, it is NOT ADA Defciency, it comes next after IL7R.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: Which of the following blood group can be given to a patient who came to the ER with Severe bleeding and unable to get matching group from the blood bank?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3. O Negative
O Negative (O-) is the universal donor for red blood cells because it lacks both A and B antigens and the Rh factor, making it compatible with any ABO group and any Rh type. O Negative can be given to anyone, regardless of their blood type, which is why it is often used in emergency situations when there is no time to type and crossmatch the blood. O Negative blood does not have A or B antigens, so it won't cause an immune reaction in recipients of blood types A, B, AB, or O. It also lacks the Rh factor, making it safe for both Rh-positive and Rh-negative patients.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 671, 672.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of anemia and exhibits characteristic target cells on peripheral blood smear. The patient is being evaluated for a potential hemoglobinopathy. Upon microscopic examination, which of the following is typically found in the center of target cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Haemoglobin
Codocytes, also known as target cells, are red blood cells that have the appearance of a shooting target with a bullseye. In optical microscopy these cells appear to have a dark center (a central, hemoglobinized area) surrounded by a white ring (an area of relative pallor), followed by dark outer (peripheral) second ring containing a band of hemoglobin. Target cells are seen in Iron deficiency anemia and thalassemia. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 647.

questions.text: The following biopsy is that of male after Orchidectomy. The specimen shows Reinke Crystaloids. Identify the tumour.?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 2. Leydig cell tumour
Reinke Crystals are seen in leydig cells and are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are made of Calretinin.




Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page. No- 974.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient initially experiences brief vision occlusion for two to three days before experiencing an abrupt loss of vision. Which of the following tests would be most effective in assessing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Serum creatinine levels
The clinical scenario given is of diabetic retinopathy. Serum creatinine levels would be the best choice as DM can lead to both retinopathy and nephropathy.

Other options: 
1. Serum ACE levels are used in sarcoidosis where serum ACE level is elevated. 
2. Quantiferon- Gold TB test is used for diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
3. New studies shows correlation with serum homocysteine and Diabetic Retinopathy but not linked to nephropathy. 

Online Reference:
Huang K, Liang Y, Wang K, Ma Y, Wu J, Luo H, Yi B. Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired. Front Clin Diabetes Healthc. 2022 May 12;3:831128. doi: 10.3389/fcdhc.2022.831128. PMID: 36992775; PMCID: PMC10012155.

questions.text: A 50-year-old industrial worker arrives at the OPD with a cough and dyspnea. Upon examination, it was discovered that he had lung fibrosis and pleural thickening. The lung biopsy resulted in the following discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asbestosis
The given clinical history is suggestive of Asbestosis and in histopathology image Asbestos bodies are shown. It is an occupational lung disease especially seen in shipping industry. Occurs because of chronic exposure to Asbestos. Patient complaints of cough, dyspnea. It usually affects the lower lobes of lung and presents as —Pleural plaque (Most Common Lesion), Lung Cancer or malignant mesothelioma (Most specific finding of asbestosis, needs about 25 years of exposure). Histopathology demonstrates asbestos/ferruginous bodies (dumbbell shaped bodies).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of cancer presents with nephrotic syndrome, characterized by edema, proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. Based on the association between cancer and kidney diseases, which of the following nephropathies is most typically linked to cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Membranous glomerulonephritis
Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most typical nephropathy linked to malignancy. In 20–30% of cases, MGN is secondary and is associated with a malignancy (solid tumors of the breast, lung, colon), infection (hepatitis B, HIV, syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis), rheumatologic disorders such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, IgG4 diseases, or drug exposure.

Histology of Membranous glomerulonephritis showing diffuse glomerular basement membrane thickening. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is both morphogenic and mitogenic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Bone morphogenetic protein 
 
  • Bone morphogenetic protein constitutes a group of pivot morphogenetic signals involved in the development of heart, central nervous system, cartilage as well as post-natal bone development. 
  • Bone morphogenic proteins activate MAP kinase and help in mitosis, hence it is mitogenic also. 
  • Recombinant human BMPs are used in orthopedic applications such as spinal fusions, non-unions and oral surgery. 
All other options only have mitogenic role. 

Reference: Harrison's Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2856.

questions.text: A 19 year old woman came to OPD with history of unprotected intercourse. Which of the following cannot be used for post-coital contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1)  Desogestrel 
After having sex, women may use emergency contraception (EC), sometimes known as emergency postcoital contraception, to avoid unwanted pregnancy. Desogestrel is not as an emergency contraceptive.

Emergency Contraception Methods:
1. Progestin-only Pill-0.75 mg levonorgestrel 2 doses 12 hours apart with 72 hours
2. Copper-containing IUD within 5 days(Gold standard)
3. Combined oral contraceptive pills that can be used for emergency contraception when taken in multiple doses 12-24 hours apart, within 72 hours.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 347.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient with a history of hyperlipidemia and a previous myocardial infarction presents to the clinic for follow-up. Despite being on statins his LDL cholesterol levels remain elevated. The physician is considering additional lipid-lowering therapy to further reduce LDL cholesterol levels. Which of the following drugs, known for its ability to inhibit PCSK9 and lower LDL cholesterol, would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1- Evolocumab. PCSK- 9 causes Lysosomal degradation of LDL receptors hence reducing LDL uptake. PCSK-9 inhibitors prevents this degradation hence increasing LDL uptake. Eg- Alirocumab and Evolocumab.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 740.

questions.text: Retigabine is being used to treat a patient with a seizure disorder (focal seizures), although the patient's seizures are not under control at this time. Which of the following sentences represents the right next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 2)  Increase the dose of retigabine

Retigabine is a potassium channel opener used as an adjunctive treatment for focal seizures. If a patient's seizures are not well-controlled with the current dose of retigabine, the next appropriate step is to increase the dose, provided the drug is well tolerated and no contraindications exist, rather than adding on another drug. 

Other options:

  1. Switch to carbamazepine: While carbamazepine is a common first-line treatment for focal seizures, switching without first considering dose adjustments for retigabine is not recommended. 

  2. Decrease the dose of retigabine: Decreasing the dose would be inappropriate if the seizures are not controlled. Typically, dose reduction is considered only if there are side effects or adverse reactions.

  3. Continue the same dose of retigabine: If seizures are not controlled with the current dose, simply continuing the same dose is unlikely to help. Increasing the dose or adding another antiepileptic drug is required. 

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: A pregnant female who was a known case of leprosy developed moderate type 2 lepra reaction. Best treatment for her would be?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Continue MDT and add steroids.
Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), is an acute inflammatory complication of leprosy. It is characterized by painful skin nodules, fever, malaise, arthritis and inflammation in various organs. MDT is NOT stopped in Lepra reactions as stopping drug may cause treatment failure. MDT is safe in Pregnancy. The first line management of moderate-severe type 2 reaction is oral steroids. Steroids are also safe in pregnancy. Thalidomide is the gold standard treatment of ENL but should not be given to pregnant females due to its known teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects like phocomelia. Hence, in a pregnant female would be to add steroids.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1387, 1390.

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology- Volume II, 9th edition, Page no 28.16.

choices.text: Inhibition of sterol of the cell wall
Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

questions.text: Dapsone is employed as an immunomodulator, antifungal, and antibacterial. What process underlies each of these actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis
Dapsone Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis. Dapsone is a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase (folP1/P2) in the folate pathway and a structural analogue of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA). Dapsone's impact on this evolutionarily conserved route also explains why it has antibacterial, anti-protozoal, and antifungal properties. Dapsone is also used in dermatitis herpetiformis as an immunomodulator as it inhibits chemotaxis of neutrophils. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 831.

choices.text: Block of Cardio-accelerator fibers of synthetic origin

questions.text: The anesthetist used high doses of bupivacaine to do a subarachnoid block on a 46-year-old male patient. He was discovered to have 72/44 mm Hg blood pressure and a 52/min heart rate after 10 minutes. The block's level was confirmed to be T6 upon inspection. What is the likely cause of the bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Reverse Bainbridge reflex
The Bainbridge reflex or Bainbridge effect (also called the atrial reflex) is a cardiovascular reflex causing an increase in heart rate in response to increased stretching of the wall of the right atrium due to increased filling of the right atrium with venous blood. A “reverse” Bainbridge reflex has been proposed to explain the decreases in heart rate observed under conditions in which venous return is reduced, such as during spinal and epidural anesthesia, controlled hypotension, and severe hemorrhage.

The Bezold–Jarisch reflex involves a variety of cardiovascular and neurological processes which cause hypopnea, hypotension and bradycardia in response to noxious stimuli detected in the cardiac ventricles. following i.v. injection of Capsaicin, Veratridine, 5HT etc. Similar to J-Reflex in lungs by J Receptors.


Online Reference: Crystal, George J. PhD, FAHA; Salem, M. Ramez MD. The Bainbridge and the “Reverse” Bainbridge Reflexes: History, Physiology, and Clinical Relevance. Anesthesia & Analgesia 114(3):p 520-532, March 2012. | DOI: 10.1213/ANE.0b013e3182312e21

questions.text: A patient is being treated with indinavir, zidovudine, lamivudine, and ketoconazole. Which drug is responsible for his development of central obesity, nephrolithiasis, hyperlipidemia, and breast hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Indinavir 
Protease inhibitors like indinavir can cause nephrolithiasis. Protease inhibitors frequently cause gynecomastia/breast enlargement, dyslipidemia, and obesity. Gynecomastia and breast enlargement are possible adverse effects of Ketoconazole, although none of the others are observed. Zidovudine and stavudine, two NRTIs, produce lipodystrophy and not obesity.

ART Side effects- 



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 865.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with acute hypertensive crisis is being treated with intravenous nitroprusside to rapidly lower blood pressure. Nitroprusside works by releasing cyanide and other metabolites that cause vasodilation. Which of the following mechanisms does nitroprusside's active metabolite use to achieve its effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Guanyl cyclase
Sodium nitroprusside active metabolite is Nitric oxide. Nitric oxide activates guanylyl cyclase and raises levels of cyclic GMP. Myosin light chain phosphorylase, which is dephosphorylated by protein kinase G when cyclic GMP is activated, relaxes the smooth muscles in blood vessels.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 544.

questions.text: All of the following medications metabolism is inhibited by Ritonavir with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Phenytoin 

Ritonavir is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor and is known to increase the plasma concentrations of many drugs by inhibiting their metabolism. Phenytoin, however, is a CYP3A4 enzyme inducer and reduces the plasma levels of ritonavir, hence it's metabolism is not inhibited by Ritonavir.

 


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1255.

choices.text: Osteoporosis leading to hip fracture in women

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman has been on long-term proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). During a routine follow-up, she reports no current gastrointestinal symptoms, but the physician is reviewing potential risks associated with prolonged PPI use. Which of the following is not a recognized side effect of long-term PPI therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypothyroidism
Proton Pump Inhibitors have not yet been found to cause hypothyroidism. PPIs inhibit acid secretion - their long-term use increases the chances of infections like Community-acquired pneumonia and Clostridium difficile( since gastric acid kills microorganisms). Decreased acid production inhibits calcium absorption in gut leading to osteoporosis. 

* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of Rho kinase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 
Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension. Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina. Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.

Other Options: 
Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is started on a new medication that requires rapid therapeutic effect. The physician decides to administer a loading dose to quickly achieve the desired plasma concentration. When calculating the appropriate loading dose, which of the following pharmacokinetic parameters is the most important determinant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Volume of distribution 
Loading Dose is a single or few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning to attain target concentration rapidly.
Thus, loading dose is governed only by V and not by CL or t½.
Variables are used to calculate the loading dose:
  • Cp = desired peak concentration of drug,
  • F = bioavailability, 
  • Vss = volume of distribution of drug at steady state,
Loading dose= Cp*Vss/F
    

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 41.

choices.text: Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A
Drug B increases the systemic metabolism of drug A
Drug B decreases the intestinal absorption of drug A
Drug B increases the renal clearance of drug A

questions.text:
The data for drug A's AUC alone and when coupled with drug B are shown in the following table. The p value is 0.0
DRUG Area Under The Curve (AUC)
A alone 550 \(\pm\) 150
A plus B 850 \(\pm\) 150
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A
The most accurate interpretation of this data is that Drug B reduces the First Pass Metabolism of Drug A. AUC (Area under the curve) demonstrates the extent of absorption of a drug. The given data has a p-value < 0.01 which is significant. According to the given data, AUC of drug A is increased when combined with drug B. This implies that drug A is absorbed better when combined with drug B.
First - pass metabolism refers to the metabolism of a drug that occurs in the liver and intestine after absorption from the gastrointestinal tract before it reaches the systemic circulation. If first - pass metabolism is reduced, more of the drug will reach the systemic circulation, resulting in increased bioavailability and a higher AUC.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 34.

questions.text: Which of the following medications induces P-glycoprotein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifampicin
P-glycoprotein (MDR 1) is a pump that causes efflux of absorbed drugs in the intestine and brush border cells of renal epithelia thus Inducing or inhibiting MDR 1 contributes towards their bioavailability and Toxicity profiles. 

Effects of Rifampicin on MDR 1 (P-gp):
  • ↑ Transcription activity
  • ↑ Expression in duodenum
  • ↑ Expression in primary hepatocyte
  • ↑ Expression in brush border cells in renal epithelium
Option 1, 2 and 3 Drugs are inhibitors of P glycoprotein.

Drugs that inhibits P-glycoprotein: (CAVE-Q)
  • Cyclosporine
  • Clarithromycin
  • Amiodarone
  • Verapamil
  • Erythromycin
  • Quinidine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 87.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient undergoing a minor surgical procedure is administered an inhalational agent for analgesia. The anesthesiologist selects a gas known for its potent analgesic properties, commonly used in both dental procedures and labor due to its rapid onset and minimal systemic effects. Among the following options, which gas is considered the most potent analgesic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nitrous oxide
Most potent analgesic agent among following is nitrous oxide. Nitrous oxide has analgesic actions thought to be mediated by activation of opioid receptors in the periaqueductal grey of the midbrain. This leads to modulation of nociceptive pathways through the release of norepinephrine and activation of α2−adrenoceptors in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. NOTE: Nitric oxide, CO2 and oxygen do not have any analgesic/anesthetic action. Only nitrous oxide is an anaesthetic amongst these. Hence, the answer by elimination. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 405.

choices.text: Alpha-1 agonist action leading to peripheral vasoconstriction
Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Releases noradrenaline and causes positive inotropic effect
Direct action on heart via beta-1 receptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is admitted to the ICU with acute circulatory shock. To improve his hemodynamic status, dopamine infusion is initiated. Which of the following actions of dopamine is not beneficial in acute shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Dopamine at low concentrations (< 2mcg/kg per minute) primarily acts on vascular D1 receptors, especially in the renal, mesenteric, and coronary beds. By activating adenylyl cyclase and raising intracellular concentrations of cyclic AMP, D1 receptor stimulation leads to vasodilation and reducing cardiac load. The net result is a decrease in blood pressure and an increase in cardiac contractility. Infusion of low doses of dopamine causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow and Na+- K+ -ATPase pump. Increased renal perfusion and decrease in blood pressure caused by dopamine due to D1 agonism (at low doses) doesn’t improves survival in acute shock. As circulating Dopamine concentrations rise, Dopamine is able to activate β adrenergic receptors to further increase cardiac contractility. At very high concentrations, circulating Dopamine activates α adrenergic receptors in the vasculature, thereby causing vasoconstriction; thus, high concentrations of Dopamine increase blood pressure, i.e, a concentration  of 10mcg/kg/min infusion.
Option 1, 3 and 4 all points towards a Vasoconstrictive action on vasculature and a positive inotropic effect on heart.


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 298.

choices.text: Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
Prodrugs and needs generation of active metabolites

questions.text: Why does PPI act longer despite having a short half-life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) are a type of pharmaceutical drug used to reduce the production of stomach acid. Despite their relatively short half-lives of around two hours, they can still cause prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 48 hours, due to their effect on the proton pumps which produce the acid. The PPIs bind to and irreversibly inhibit the proton pump molecules, meaning that for acid secretion to occur again, new proton pumps need to be synthesized. Therefore, although the PPIs are short-lived, their effects can be prolonged due to the time taken for new proton pumps to be made.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of saquinavir will improve its bioavailability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ritonavir
Saquinavir is a protease inhibitor used in anti - retroviral therapy. They are metabolized by CYP3A4 and hence act as inhibitors of CYP3A4. Ritonavir is the most potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and is used in combination with other protease inhibitors to boost their action and bioavailability. Cimetidine is also an inhibitor of CYP3A4 but since Ritonavir is the most potent inhibitor, Ritonavir is the most correct option. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 33.

questions.text: A female patient receiving tamoxifen therapy has unilateral breast cancer. Which of the following negative effects is connected to tamoxifen use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Endometrial carcinoma
Tamoxifen is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) used as adjuvant therapy for estrogen receptor (ER)-positive breast cancer. It has tissue-specific actions:


* Following are the side effects of tamoxifen:
  • Selective estrogen activation effect (due to which blood clots, stroke and endometrial cancer is seen)
  • Increased tumor or bone pain
  • Hot flashes
  • Mood swings and depression
  • Hair thinning
  • Constipation
  • Loss of libido
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 377.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters determine a drug's loading dose?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) Volume of distribution

Loading dose= Volume of distribution* plasma concentration
Loading Dose is a single or few quickly repeated doses given in the beginning to attain target concentration rapidly.
Loading dose depends on the volume of distribution and not on CL or t½.
Loading Dose immediately raises the concentration of the medication in plasma to the desired concentration and given when the delay to reach steady state is significant, as it is for medicines having extended half-lives. The proportionality factor that links the overall amount of drug in the body to the concentration is the volume of distribution.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 41.

questions.text: Identify the pathogen based on the cell wall shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 4. Aspergillus fumigatus.
The cell wall of Aspergillus fumigatus, a common species of Aspergillus, contains several constituents. The major components of the cell wall include:

  • Chitin: Chitin is a polysaccharide composed of N-acetylglucosamine units. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

  • Glucan: Glucan is a polysaccharide composed of glucose units. It contributes to the integrity of the cell wall and provides structural support.

  • Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins that contain mannose residues. They are important for cell wall organization, adhesion, and immune modulation.

β-(1,3)-Glucan: Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall also contains β-(1,3)-glucan, which is another type of polysaccharide composed of glucose units. It is an important target for immune recognition.




Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 352,393,593,594,612,613 .

questions.text: Identify which virus has the lifecycle listed below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 2. HSV
The given lifecycle shows the nuclear material of the virus being DNA so only HSV(member of herpes family) and Herpes virus have DNA as their genetic material. Since in the image alpha, beta and gamma protein are shown which is specific to HSV, the given image is of HSV replication. Steps of HSV replication cycle— 1. Binding to cell surface. 2. Entry after fusion of the membranes. 3. Capsid transport to the nucleus. 4. Transcription and translation. 5. Replication followed by capsid assembly. 6. Glycosylation 7. Glycoprotein export to the cell surface 8. Glycoprotein - containing plasma membrane endocytosis. 9. Envelopment : Glycoproteins within early endosomes fare with capsids in the cytoplasm. 10. Viral release.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 437.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about WHO-SAGE criteria HPV vaccination in 9-14 years of age?
questions.solution:

WHO recommends: A one or two-dose schedule for girls aged 9-14 years. A one or two-dose schedule for girls and women aged 15-20 years. Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21 years.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male recently underwent a renal transplant and is currently on immunosuppressive therapy including tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil. He presents to the clinic with complaints of low-grade fever, malaise, and mild leukopenia. The physician suspects an opportunistic infection commonly seen in post-transplant patients due to their immunocompromised state. Among the following viral infections, which is considered the most common cause of infection in post-transplant patients?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1. CMV (Cytomegalovirus).

Cytomegalovirus is the most common cause of infection in post-transplant patients due to immunosuppression required to prevent graft rejection. CMV infection can cause a wide range of complications, including pneumonitis, hepatitis, gastrointestinal disease, and CMV syndrome, which presents with fever, malaise, and leukopenia.

Other options

  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) can cause post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) but is not the most common post-transplant infection.
  • Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause shingles due to reactivation, but it is less common than CMV and the clinical history does not suggest any vesicles. 
  • BK virus primarily affects renal transplant patients, leading to BK virus nephropathy, but it is not as common as CMV infection overall.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 479.

Fasciolopsis Buski in humans and pigs, the adult worm resides in the duodenum or jejunum. 
Hepatic Fasciola has leaf-shaped with a body that is flattened dorsoventrally. The parasite is hermaphrodite. Definitive host: Sheep serve as its primary definitive host, however it can also be detected in the human biliary tract. Freshwater snails are the first intermediate hosts (Lymnaea).  Aquatic vegetations serve as a second intermediate host. Metacercariae encysted on unprocessed aquatic vegetation is the infectious form. 
Schistosomes are dioecious, that is, sexes are separate.
DOC for trematodes is praziquantel.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient from a rural area presents with right upper quadrant abdominal discomfort. Imaging studies of the liver reveal a slow-growing, infiltrative mass with alveolar-like patterns. Serological testing is being considered to confirm the diagnosis. Based on the clinical presentation and radiologic findings which of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
1. E. granulosus
2. E. multilocularis
3. Cysticercus cellulosae 
4. Orientia
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 2. Echinococcus multilocularis
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of malignant hydatid cyst. The liver develops many lesions that resemble alveoli as a result of Echinococcus multilocularis. It is the cause of alveolar hydatid cysts disease or malignant hydatid cyst. It manifests as numerous tiny liver cysts.
Echinococcus granulosus is the cause of unilocular hydatid cyst disease.

Imaging finding of malignant hydatid cyst. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: The graphic depicts the organism that causes microcephaly being transmitted through the placenta. Identify the most likely organism.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1.Zika virus
The organism responsible for microcephaly here is Zika virus, because the disease is transmitted by aedes mosquito. Zika virus can spread via sexual route or by vertical transmission. 
Other infections in which microcephaly me be seen:
i. Rubella
ii. CMV
iii. Toxoplasmosis
iv. Varicella

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 661.

questions.text: The maximum usefulness of polysaccharide vaccine 23 for streptococcal pneumonia infection is observed in which of the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Sickle cell anemia
Patients with sickle cell disease are most likely to benefit from this vaccination. The spleen identifies capsulated organisms like  Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, sickled cells in sickle cell anemia obstruct the spleen's blood arteries, which causes splenic infraction resulting in functional asplenia(no spleen). As a result of this asplenia, pneumococcal infection risk is enhanced. Pneumococcal vaccination (PCV-23) is therefore administered to these patients as a preventive step to lower this risk. Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine is not given in children < 2 years as they have immature immune system and cannot produce required titre of protective antibodies. In recurrent otitis media Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine may be used not polysaccharide vaccine. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 228.

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B infection with Hepatitis E super infection
Co- infection with Hepatitis B & Hepatitis E

questions.text: The patient has increased SGPT and SGOT, positive HBsAg, negative Anti-HBc IgM, and positive Anti-Hepatitis E IgM. Their Bilirubin level is 0.9 mg/dl. The patient suffers from:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. 1. Chronic Hepatitis B infection with Hepatitis E super infection
In this case, the patient was already infected with hepatitis B and after that gets  infected with an acute strain of hepatitis E virus as the patient 's lab reports show:
  • positive HBsAg, negative Anti-HBc IgM- suggestive of chronic infection  of hepatitis B
  •  positive Anti-Hepatitis E IgM- suggestive of acute hepatitis E infection
This is known as  superinfection of hepatitis E on hepatitis B and can cause a more severe form of illness than if the patient had only been infected with either virus alone. Superinfection occurs when a person is already infected with a particular virus and is then infected with a different strain of the same virus.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 553.

questions.text: The presence of COV- 2 antibodies in blood indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 3. Past infection even if asymptomatic
The presence of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in the blood indicates that the person has been previously infected with the virus, regardless of whether they had symptoms or not. Antibodies are part of the immune response and generally appear 1 to 3 weeks after infection. They are used to determine past exposure to the virus, not the current viral load or infectivity.

Other options: 
1. It does not indicate a high viral load — that would be detected via PCR testing.
2. It doesn't mean a high risk of reinfection as antibodies decrease the rate of reinfection. 
3. It also does not correspond to the window period, which is the time before antibodies appear following infection.

So, detecting antibodies confirms that the individual was infected in the past, even if they were asymptomatic at the time.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 563.

choices.text: Resides in the epithelial layer of mucosa.

questions.text: Identify the correct option about gamma-delta T-cells from the following options-
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option1. Resides in the epithelial layer of mucosa.
5–10% of the T cells in circulation are gamma-delta T cells, located in epithelial surfaces. They have gamma-delta heterodimer receptors, which have limited diversity and can identify phospholipid antigens, as opposed to helper and cytotoxic T cells, which have alpha-beta heterodimer receptors. They differ from the conventional alpha-beta T cells by the fact that they do not require antigen processing and MHC presentation of peptides. They are part of innate immunity as the gamma-delta receptors exhibit limited diversity for the antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: A 40 year old female came to your OPD with genital ulcer. You take smear from the ulcer, stain it and under light microscope you get the view as shown in the image. Pick out the responsible organism.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 3. Trichomonas vaginalis
The above image is of trichomonas vaginalis. Women who are infected typically have a translucent "halo" surrounding their superficial cell nucleus on a cervical smear. It is unreliably detected by studying a genital discharge or with a cervical smear because of their low sensitivity.
A wet mount was previously used to diagnose T. vaginalis, and "corkscrew" motility was noted.

Other options: 
1. Chlamydia will show inclusion bodies in light microscopy
2. Treponema pallidum is visualized under fluorescent microscopy as spiral organisms.
4. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is seen as diplococci inside and outside of neutrophils under light microscopy. 

Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 37.

questions.text: An abattoir worker presented with a malignant pustule on his hand that progressed to form an ulcer. The smear was taken from the ulcer and sent to a laboratory for investigation. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1. Cutaneous anthrax
The diagnosis is cutaneous anthrax. Malignant pustule is present in cutaneous anthrax and animals that are infected by ingestion of spores present in soil. It is also called hide potter's disease because it is seen in abattoir workers. 

Other options:-

Cutaneous anthrax
