questions.text: According to Gustafson's method, what is the most significant indicator of age determination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Root transparency
Dentin becomes less visible with age, as mineral deposits fill the wide dentin tubules which become smaller and less translucent. This process of gradual mineralization is the most dependable way of determining a person's age. After around 30 years of age, the dentin becomes transparent due to mineralization and osteoporosis. This makes Root transparency the single most important indicator for Gustafson method of age analysis. Transparency of root occurs from below upwards in lower jaw and from above downwards in upper jaw. It is the most reliable of all criteria.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 69.

questions.text: Police took a 25-year-old unidentified individual from the roadside who was vomiting, disoriented, and experiencing altered senses to the hospital department. His BP was 90/70 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, body temperature was -36.4°C, and breathing rate was 11/min. He had bilateral pin-point pupils when examined. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Opioid poisoning.
The classical presentation of miosis with respiratory depression is suggestive of opioid poisoning. Opioids cause physical dependence. Its effects are as follows:
  • Miosis
  • Orthostatic hypotension 
  • Respiratory depression 
  • Stupor
  • Coma
  • Antidote – Naloxone
The classical triad of acute opioid poisoning is pin point pupil, respiratory depression and altered sensorium.

Other options: 
Option 1: The clinical signs of pontine hemorrhage are:
Respiratory disturbances and failure
  • Tetraplegia
  • decerebrate posture
  • hyperthermia
  • pinpoint pupils
Option 2: Features of miosis and respiratory depression are less likely in an independent case of hypothermia.
Option 4: Dhatura poisoning patient will present with
  • Fever
  • Altered mental status
  • Dilated pupils
  • Dry skin and mucosa
Treatment:  physostigmine 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Which of these is not suggestive of domestic violence in a child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Wormian bones

* Audio Explanation: 

Wormian bones are small bones present in between sutures. Sometimes they occur normally and also Osteogenesis imperfecta causes Wormian Bones, not child abuse.
The complex of non-accidental injuries sustained by infants and young children as a result of abuse is referred to by a number of names, including battered child syndrome, shaken infant syndrome, stress-related infant abuse, and non-accidental trauma. The diagnostic triad consists of subdural hematomas, multiple long bone fractures, and retinal haemorrhage .

Highlighted bones are the wormian bones. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 445.

questions.text:
A pathologist is performing a fetal autopsy to investigate the cause of intrauterine fetal demise. As part of the standard procedure, the internal cavities are systematically opened to examine the internal organs and identify any congenital anomalies or pathological findings. Which of the following body cavities is typically opened first during a fetal autopsy?
1. Cranium 
2. Thorax
3. Abdomen
4. Pericardial
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Cranium.
 The correct order of conducting fetal autopsy is Cranium > Abdomen > Thorax. Cranium of fetus is opened first because the cranial bones are soft and moldable and thus needs to be opened first to prevent distortion and artifacts during postmortem.  Abdomen is opened before thorax to note highest point of diaphragm, to differentiate between still birth and live birth. Cavities that contain trace evidence are opened first compared to cavities that contain maximum evidence are opened last to prevent artifacts.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33rd Edition, Page No 438-440.

questions.text: The same needle that was used on a patient who had HIV was also used on another patient. The latter patient is confirmed to have HIV infection, according to tests. Which part of the Indian penal code penalises the doctor for this negligence?
questions.solution:
The doctor here has done a negligent act which has caused HIV transmission to a patient. This is punishable under Section 269 of IPC.

Section 269 : Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life. Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six month, or with fine, or with both.


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 55.

questions.text: Which of the following section of IPC defines perjury as a crime and which section outlines its punishment?
questions.solution:

Perjury is an offense defined in Section 191 of the Indian Penal Code. Perjury refers to giving false evidence - It arises when a person's statements under oath contradict each other and cannot be reconciled. The punishment for perjury is outlined in Section 193 of the Indian Penal Code, where imprisonment can be up to 7 years. It arises when a person's statements under oath contradict each other and cannot be reconciled.

questions.text: Which of these elements can poison someone and induce alkali illness and blind staggers in livestock?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3. Selenium.
Selenium poisoning has long been known to cause several diseases in animals, specifically blind staggers and alkali disease in livestock. For many years, only its detrimental consequences were studied, with both acute and chronic selenium poisoning observed in the Great Plains of North America as blind staggers and alkali disease in livestock respectively. Selenium deficiency in humans cause Keshan's disease, a type of dilated cardiomyopathy, first observed in Keshan province of China. 

Other options:- 
1. Magnesium- deficiency can causes cardiac arrythmias and tetany in humans and livestock.
2. Manganese deficiency is linked with infertility in adults.
4. Molybdenum deficiency or toxicity is not linked to any major disease. 

Reference: MacFarquhar JK, Broussard DL, Melstrom P, Hutchinson R, Wolkin A, Martin C, Burk RF, Dunn JR, Green AL, Hammond R, Schaffner W, Jones TF. Acute selenium toxicity associated with a dietary supplement. Arch Intern Med. 2010 Feb 8;170(3):256-61. doi: 10.1001/archinternmed.2009.495. PMID: 20142570; PMCID: PMC3225252.

questions.text: A forensic examiner is evaluating a victim of sexual assault using Toluidine blue dye during the medical examination. This dye helps in highlighting certain findings that may not be visible to the naked eye. What does it primarily detect?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 3.  Recent micro injuries
The most important benefit from Toluidine blue dye is the ability to identify the microtrauma caused by blunt force trauma to the genitalia. Toluidine blue dye, a nuclear stain, binds to denuded tissues, is used to improve the identification of genital micro lacerations during the examinations of rape victims.


Reference: Sridharan G, Shankar AA. Toluidine blue: A review of its chemistry and clinical utility. J Oral Maxillofac Pathol. 2012 May;16(2):251-5. doi: 10.4103/0973-029X.99081. PMID: 22923899; PMCID: PMC3424943.

questions.text: Which among the following is least used in identification of dead body?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1. Nail

2. Teeth are one of the most reliable tools for identification in forensic science. They are highly resistant to decomposition, fire, and trauma, and can remain intact long after other tissues have decomposed. Dental records, including X-rays, dental charts, and photographs, can be matched accurately to confirm identity, especially in mass disasters.

3. Fingerprints are considered the gold standard for personal identification. They are unique to every individual, including identical twins, and remain unchanged throughout life. Even after death, if the skin is preserved, fingerprinting can still be effectively used to establish identity.

4. Bones play a vital role in identifying deceased individuals, especially in cases where only skeletal remains are recovered. Through osteological analysis, forensic experts can determine the person’s age, sex, ancestry, and stature. In some cases, DNA can be extracted from bone marrow to confirm identity.

1. Nails, while sometimes helpful in forensic investigations (e.g., collecting DNA from beneath the nails), are the least used method for identification of a dead body. They do not have distinctive patterns like fingerprints, detailed records like teeth or provide stature and sex like bones, and they decompose relatively quickly, offering limited use for identification purposes.



Reference: Simpson's Forensic Medicine, 12th Edition, Page No: 53.

questions.text: A young man who had been in a fight had trouble extending his distal interphalangeal joint. An X-ray was conducted, and it came out clean. What should the patient's next course of action be?

questions.text: A patient complains of back pain that radiates to posterolateral leg, loss of medial hamstring reflex and decreased sensation along anterolateral leg, large toe web and dorsum of foot. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. L4-L5 disc prolapse.
In disc prolapse, the nerve root just below the disc is affected. Thus, the above clinical features are seen due to involvement of L5 nerve root which will be seen in L4-L5 disc prolapse.

Other options: 
  • Option 1- L5-S1 disc prolapse will result in compression of S1 nerve root causing loss of ankle jerk and decreased sensation along lateral malleolus, lateral foot, heel and web of fourth and fifth toes.
  • Option 3- L3-L4 disc prolapse will result in compression of L4 nerve root causing weakness of quadriceps muscle and decreased sensation along posterolateral leg, anterior knee, medial malleolus and medial foot.
  • Option 4- L5 fracture will present with tenderness but usually doesn't present with radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 60yr old post menopausal woman presents to OPD with DEXA scan reports which showed a score of -2.5. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 6 months back. She is not a smoker and doesn’t take alcohol. Which of the following should be the first line of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Alendronate.
In the given scenario the T score is -2.5 SD in DEXA scan, it is diagnostic of osteoporosis. It is imperative to start the female on treatment since she has a past history of Colle's fracture. The drug of choice for osteoporosis is bisphosphonates and among them, it is alendronate as it can be administered orally unlike others which require parenteral administration. The additional treatment should be calcium and vitamin D3. It helps attenuate hungry bone syndrome associated with bisphosphonate therapy.
HRT is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment due to the increased risk of breast cancer, stroke, and cardiovascular disease.
Note- Osteoporosis is a quantitative and not qualitative bone disease. Hence, the lab parameters will remain normal. DEXA scan is the investigation of choice for Osteoporosis. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 309

questions.text: What method is the most effective for evaluating eustachian tube function?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 1. Tympanometry. 
Eustachian tube function is assessed by both tympanometry and Politzer test.
Politzer test is an old method(rarely used now) is a manual method of opening Eustachian tube by air pressure. This method is technically cumbersome and less accurate. 
Tympanometry is the most effective and commonly used method for evaluating Eustachian tube function. It objectively measures the movement of the tympanic membrane in response to changes in air pressure, reflecting the pressure within the middle ear — which is directly influenced by Eustachian tube function. Hence, Tympanometry is the most accurate answer to the question. 


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Head and Neck surgery ,7th Edition - page 63

choices.text: Acts on mechanoreceptors of outer hair cell

questions.text: What is the initial mechanism of action of intra-tympanic gentamicin given for the treatment of Meniere's disease:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2.Binds to hair cell Na+ -K+ ATPase channel in vestibular hair cell
Gentamicin, when administered via trans-tympanic injection, primarily affects vestibular type I and type II hair cells while sparing the cochlear inner and outer hair cells. This makes it a vestibulotoxic drug. Gentamicin targets the transport channels (Na+ K+ ATPase) on vestibular hair cells, allowing it to accumulate in these cells and lead to their death, thereby alleviating vertigo symptoms without compromising hearing, as it does not impact inner and outer hair cells or the stria vascularis. It's noteworthy that vestibular type I hair cells are particularly susceptible to damage from Gentamicin.
Outer hair cells are cochlear hair cells, related to auditory function, not to vestibular symptoms of Meniere's disease. 


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 115

questions.text: A patient will undergo general anesthesia for hernia operation. Which of these drugs is most frequently used prior to administration of  anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, Glycopyrrolate is the drug used most frequently prior to anesthesia. 

 
Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic medication and is used to decrease stomach, mouth, and throat secretions prior to surgery.

  • Glycopyrrolate is a synthetic quaternary ammonium derivative of atropine. Due to its quaternary structure, which is charged in nature, it cannot cross the blood brain barrier and hence its anticholinergic effects are confined to the periphery. Hence, it is used more frequently compared to other anti-cholinergics like the other options, Atropine, Promethazine and Scopolamine. 
  • The activity of glycopyrrolate also lasts longer than that of atropine.
  • Often, anesthetic agents are combined with premedication of a barbiturate or benzodiazepine and an antisialagogue (e.g., glycopyrrolate) to facilitate management. The premedications reduce the dose requirement for anesthetic agent, and the antisialagogue reduces the sometimes troublesome salivation and respiratory secretions. This helps in prevention of aspiration.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 666.

choices.text: Assess the patient’s response, call for help, Check carotid pulse, start CPR
Check carotid pulse, start CPR, call for help, defibrillate
Defibrillate, assess response, check carotid pulse, maintain airway
Start CPR, call for help, defibrillate, check pulse

questions.text: A middle-aged man suddenly collapses in a public area. Following standard resuscitation protocols, which of the following sequences of steps is considered the correct initial approach?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Assess the patient’s response, call for help, Check carotid pulse, start CPR

According to the Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) algorithm, steps followed are:
  • Check scene safety,
  • Assess the patient's response,
  • Call for help,
  • Check carotid pulse,
  • Start CPR.




Reference: Adult BLS Algorithm for Healthcare Providers, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2262.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with sudden episodes of intense fear, palpitations, shortness of breath, and a feeling of impending doom. Which of the following neurotransmitters is least associated with the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option 4. Glutamate.
The given clinical scenario is of panic attack. 



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 389, 393.

questions.text:
An extremely depressed patient had ECT.  The patient received thiopental and succinylcholine from the anesthesiologist. 
How did these substances affect the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. General anesthesia and get muscle relaxation.
Electroconvulsive Therapy is passing electrical current in brain to treat psychiatric disorders like resistant depression, bipolar disorder. The two drugs given by the anaesthetist are used for providing general anaesthesia and muscle relaxation to the patient. Thiopentone is an anaesthetic agent while succinylcholine acts as a muscle relaxation. These drugs are given by an anaesthetist in modified Electroconvulsive Therapy which is the only legal form of ECT acceptable nowadays. General anesthesia is given to make patient unconscious and make the procedure pain free. Muscle relaxant is given to prevent dislocation and fracture during convulsions. 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1069.

questions.text: A young patient was admitted to hospital with acute psychosis. He wakes up and asks the nurse to call his wife who was there in the same room in the same area. Upon seeing her, he started beating her thinking that it was nurse who was masquerading as his wife. He also said she was the same nurse who gave her wrong medication 2 days back as well to make him ill, because she wanted to harm him but who was actually his wife. What syndrome he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1. Capgras syndrome
The patient has Capgras syndrome, in accordance with the description provided (the wife, a familiar person has been substituted with the nurse, an impostor). The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the conviction that an impostor has taken the place of a familiar individual.
In Frégoli’s syndrome, a person believes that different people are a same person in disguise.
Othello syndrome is delusional jealousy. The person has a false believe that his/her partner is cheating on him/her. 
.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 319, 321.

questions.text: A mood stabilizer was controlling a male patient with bipolar disorder who had previously experienced 5 bouts of mania and 1 episode of depression in the previous 8 years. However, manic symptoms started to develop as he tapered off the medication. Which of the subsequent actions needs to be taken to increase drug compliance?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1. Psychoeducation
The given clinical scenario is of Bipolar Disorder. The relapse of maniac symptoms is due to poor compliance to medication. An evidence-based therapy intervention for patients/loved ones that offer knowledge to better understand and manage sickness is known as psychoeducation (a portmanteau of psychological education). Patients and family members who receive psychoeducation are taught problem-solving, knowledge about disease and medications, strategies to prevent relapse and they are given information and tools in a compassionate setting. Results from many studies show that psychoeducation enhances rehabilitation, increased drug compliance decreases relapse rates, and benefits families.

Other options:
 

2. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a structured, goal-oriented therapy that helps patients identify and modify negative thought patterns and behaviors. While CBT is effective in managing depressive symptoms, preventing relapse, and improving functioning in bipolar disorder, it is not the first-line approach when the primary issue is medication non-compliance. It can be helpful later in therapy but isn’t ideal for addressing immediate adherence problems.

3. Supportive Psychotherapy focuses on providing emotional support, reassurance, and encouragement. It helps build the therapeutic alliance and can reduce distress, but it lacks the structured, educational approach necessary to directly address non-compliance.

4. Insight-Oriented Psychotherapy aims to explore unconscious conflicts and long-standing emotional issues contributing to psychological distress. This approach requires a patient with good insight and stability and is typically used in personality disorders or chronic conditions, not in acute management of non-adherence in bipolar disorder.



Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 1271, 1272.

questions.text: Which of the following topical drugs is not used in the treatment of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 4. Fluocinolone
The given image is of moderate-severe/ grade 3 acne vulgaris. Fluocinolone is a steroid and is not used in the treatment of acne as steroids can exacerbate acne. Treatment includes topical retinoids and anti-bacterial and oral antibiotics or isotretinoin. 


Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37, 90.38, 90.40

questions.text: A 24 years old female presented with complaints of rash on exposure to sun, after exercise, when she gets angry or on eating spicy food. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Cholinergic urticaria.
Itching, burning, tingling, warmth, or irritation precedes the onset of numerous small (1-4 mm in diameter), pruritic wheals with large, surrounding flares is suggestive of Cholinergic urticaria. This condition is caused by an increase in body temperature, which leads to the release of histamine from mast cells in the skin, histamine causes wheals with itching and tingling sensation. Exercise is the most common precipitating event for cholinergic urticaria, but any stimulus that causes sweating, including elevated environmental temperature, hot food, sauna baths, immersion in hot water, gustatory stimuli, emotional stress, and hemodialysis, can bring on an urticaria.
Chronic idiopathic urticaria has no triggering factor, wheals develop on it's own. 

Wheal 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 42.11

questions.text: A young 8 years old boy with multiple, small, pin point, shiny, papular lesions on dorsal aspect of hand, forearms and his penis also. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Lichen nitidus.
Lichen nitidus is a rare skin disorder that is characterized by small, pinhead-sized, shiny, flat-topped papules. These papules often form clusters, which can range in size from a few millimeters to up to a centimeter. They usually appear on dorsum of hand, upper arms, neck, and face, shaft of penis and may be more common in children and adolescents. The color of the papules can vary from yellow-brown, to pink or white. Lichen nitidus is asymptomatic and does not cause itching or irritation. The diagnosis of Lichen nitidus is based on the appearance of the papules. A skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis where it shows clutching the ball appearance. Treatment is usually not necessary, although topical steroids may be used to reduce any inflammation. Long-term prognosis for Lichen nitidus is excellent, as it is considered a harmless condition and self resolution occurs in most cases. 
Other options- 
1. Molluscum contagiosum will have umbilicated papules.
2 & 3. Scabies and Lichen planus will have intense itching as symptom. 



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text: A patient came with a history of joint pain and fever for one week. For which the patient took NSAIDs following which she developed a rash and hyperpigmentation on her nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (2) Chikungunya.
Based on the clinical history of fever, joint pain, a rash, and the development of brownish discoloration over the nose after one week of taking NSAIDs, the most likely diagnosis is pigmentation due to Chikungunya, a condition where the pigmentation of the nose area is quite noticeable. This sign is known as Chik sign. 
This pigmentation is not usually seen in other viral exanthems.
In contrast, in the case of a fixed drug eruption, the mucocutaneous junction and genital skin, in particular the glans is most often affected, not the nose. (hence, option (3) is incorrect).
In case of melasma the pigmentation will also occur in malar prominences and will have a chronic onset. 

Reference Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya during a recent epidemic in Calicut, north Kerala, south India, IJDVL 2010

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple hypopigmented patches on his arms and trunk. Some of the lesions are anesthetic. On examination, there is thickening of peripheral nerves. A slit-skin smear is performed and sent for bacterial index. A skin biopsy is also taken for histopathological examination. The dermatologist suspects leprosy and wants to classify the disease using the Ridley-Joplin system to guide management and prognosis. Which of the following parameters is used in the Ridley-Joplin classification of leprosy?
1. Clinical, bacteriological, immunological
2. Histopathological, clinical, therapeutic
3. Histopathological, epidemiological, therapeutics
4. Histopathological, clinical, epidemiological
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 1. Clinical, bacteriological, immunological.
The Ridley-Jopling classification for leprosy is a system designed in 1967 to classify the type of leprosy a person is affected with. It is the most widely accepted classification. The classification takes into account the degree to which patients have been affected by the disease by Clinical, bacteriological and immunological parameters and assigns them one of five stages of severity: 



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.3,28.12

questions.text: The incidence of which of the following cancer has been reduced due to the revolutionized in food preservation brought on by the advent of refrigeration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Stomach
Since the early 20th century, countries that have substituted refrigeration for traditional food-preserving methods such as salting, smoking, and pickling have seen a remarkable decrease in stomach cancer cases. Conversely, countries that still rely heavily on these old practices still have high incidences of stomach cancer. Stomach cancer increases with consumption of nitrites (salting and smoking generates nitrites), preserved food, etc. 
Other options:-
1. Esophagus cancer- caused due to smoking
3. Colon cancer occurs due to red meat consumption.
4. Oropharyngeal malignancies occur due to tobacco consumption. 


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 204.

questions.text: Unintentionally, a staple was positioned below and lateral to the iliopubic tract during laparoscopic inguinal hernia surgery. The patient reported thigh pain and soreness following the surgery. Which nerve is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of inadvertent placement of surgical stapler in the triangle of pain during laparoscopic mesh repair of inguinal hernia involving lateral cutaneous of thigh causing thigh pain.

 

Fig: Mesh fixation with tacks. 1. above the pubic bone; 2. medial to epigastric vessels; 3. lateral to inferior epigastric vessels, 4. Two centimeters above iliopubic tract

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1074.

questions.text: Which of these has the highest risk of developing pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant disorder STK 11 gene, characterized by the development of hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas. Individuals with Peutz-Jegher's syndrome have an increased risk of developing various types of cancer, including pancreatic cancer. The risk of developing pancreatic cancer in individuals with Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is estimated to be significantly higher compared to the general population. It also has mucosal lentigens. 

Arborizing hamartomatous polyp of PJ syndrome. 


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1309.

questions.text: What does Luminal type A breast Cancer mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. ER+ PR+ HER2-
Luminal A means ER + PR+ and HER2 -


* Extra edge: 

In patients with endocrine-responsive breast cancer, those with luminal A tumours may avoid chemotherapy if they have a low-risk score on Oncotype Dx® and/or clinical risk assessment online tools (e.g. https://breast.predict.nhs.uk/ tool); however, patients with a high clinical and genomic risk should be considered for chemotherapy with an anthracycline (epirubicin) or taxane-based therapy. Patients with luminal B tumours should receive an anthracycline and/or taxane-based therapy because of the greater risk of relapse. Those with HER2/neu-positive tumours should receive trastuzumab+pertuzumab along with chemotherapy (taxane + anthracycline), while those with triple negative tumours should receive chemotherapy (taxane + anthracycline). Carboplatin-based regimens may be beneficial for tumours with aggressive biology.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page. No- 931, 940.

questions.text: Which of these is the most dependable for monitoring fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Urine output
The easiest and most reliable method of assessing the adequacy of fluid resuscitation is by monitoring the urine output. 
The key to monitoring of resuscitation is urine output. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour. If the urine output drops and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion (tachycardia, cool peripheries and a high lactate/metabolic acidosis), then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given. It is important that patients are not over-resuscitated; urine output in excess of 2 mL/kg body weight per hour should warrant a decrease in infusion.
Other measures of tissue perfusion such as lactate levels can be useful, particularly in larger burns. A persistent raised lactate/metabolic acidosis can indicate a missed systemic toxicity from cyanide or carbon monoxide. Patients with underlying comorbidities, particularly cardiac or renal, will require further intensive monitoring such as central venous pressure measurement in an intensive care setting. PR and BP are not very reliable parameters for monitoring fluid resuscitation. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 671.

questions.text: A young woman came in with a bulge in the middle of her neck, as can be seen below, which movements with swallowing and tongue protrusion. Its size has remained unchanged throughout the last year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thyroglossal cyst

Thyroglossal cyst is the only cause of midline neck swelling which moves with both swallowing and tongue protrusion.

Thyroglossal Cyst
It is a fibrous cyst that presents as a regular neck mass or a lump.
They are the most common cause of midline neck masses and are generally subhyoid in location.
The mass on the neck moves during swallowing or on protrusion of the tongue because of its attachment to the tongue (foramen of cecum) via the tract of thyroid descent.

* [Extra Edge]: Treatment Of Thyroglossal Cyst

Treatment must include excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, which involves removal of the body of the hyoid bone and the suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum, together with a core of tissue on either side. This operation is known as Sistrunk’s operation and minimizes recurrence, most notably from small side branches of the thyroglossal tract.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who is having increasing trouble swallowing both food and liquids is put through a barium study. The image is seen here. What is the next stage in the patient's care?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  is 1. Upper G.I Endoscopy + Manometry
Taking into consideration the age, symptoms, history and the X-ray which shows Bird-Beak appearance, the most probable diagnosis is Achalasia Cardia. It is characterized by failure of organized esophageal peristalsis, which results in food stasis and frequently noticeable esophageal dilatation and poor relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter due to damage to the Auerbach plexus and Vagus nerve. To look for constrictions and other causes of Achalasia cardia plus for confirming the diagnosis, upper GI endoscopy with Manometry is done (which shows pressure at the level of Gastro-esophageal junction). Manometry is also used to rule out other esophageal motility disorders. 
24 hour pH monitoring is done for Gastro-esophageal reflux disorder. CECT and PET scan don't have role in esophageal motility disorders. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1122.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate management for a patient who has tenderness in the left iliac fossa with a 3-cm stone in the renal pelvis and no hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is an ideal management for a female patient with a 3 cm left renal pelvic stone with no hydroureteronephrosis or distal obstruction, and normal functioning kidneys on both sides. PCNL is minimally invasive, and can successfully treat stones of any size and location. It also reduces the risk of urine leakage and stone fragments, and allows for quick stone clearance and shorter recovery times. The procedure involves a small incision in the back through which a tiny telescope is inserted to view the stone, a laser to break up the stone and enable removal, and nephrostomy tubes to flush out the fragments.

Other options: 
2. ESWL- is used in stones < 2cm. 
3. Diuretics are not used in the treatment of renal stones.
4. Medical dissolution therapy with Potassium Citrate used in uric acid stones <1cm. 


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1477.

questions.text: 45-year-old woman arrived with a history of a painless breast mass in the left upper quadrant measuring 6 cm by 5 cm with no axillary lymph nodes. A true-cut biopsy was indicative of ductal carcinoma in situ . After undergoing surgery, all tumor tissue was removed with sufficient margins, and a postoperative HPE revealed DCIS with high grade tumor and necrosis and 14 mm of margin clearance. Which of the following is subsequently required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Adjuvant radiotherapy


The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is used to guide treatment decisions for Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) based on four factors:  (1)Patient Age, (2) Tumor Size, (3)Histologic Grade (including necrosis) and (4)Surgical Margin Width. 

Each factor is scored from 1 to 3, with higher scores indicating a greater risk of recurrence. The total score ranges from 4 to 12, categorizing patients into low, intermediate, or high-risk groups. Low risk group requires excision, intermediate group requires excision+ Radiotherapy while high risk group requires mastectomy. 

Van Nuys prognostic index:





In the current scenario as given in the question - 

Age: 45 years → Score: 2 (Age 40–60 years)
Tumor Size: 6 cm (60 mm) × 5 cm (50 mm) → Score: 3 (Size >40 mm)
Histologic Grade: High-grade with necrosis → Score: 3
Margin Width: 14 mm → Score: 1(Margins >10 mm)
Total Score = 2+3+3+1 = 9

Hence, patient needs to be given adjuvant Radiotherapy i.e option 3 as per VNPI (Van Nuys Prognostic Index)

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 844.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument given in the image below-
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Monopolar cautery.
The instrument in the given image is used to perform Monopolar Cautery. With the use of a specialised tool, electrosurgery uses high-frequency electrical current to cut, coagulate, desiccate, and fulgurate tissue. It can be carried out using either monopolar or bipolar energy.

Other options: 

Bipolar cautery 

Harmonic scalpel 

Ligasure


Reference: Cordero I. Electrosurgical units - how they work and how to use them safely. Community Eye Health. 2015;28(89):15-6. PMID: 26435589; PMCID: PMC4579996.

choices.text: Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by second part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment
Superior mesenteric artery has a normal angle between 38-65 degree in relation to duodenum
Strong's procedure is corrective surgery in which ligament of Treitz divided.
Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is characterized by an angle less than 25 degree due to loss of intervening mesenteric pad of fat

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about superior mesenteric artery syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. Superior mesenteric artery is compressed by second part of duodenum at the ligament of Treitz attachment
Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome: It is a cause of UGI obstruction from the compression of the third portion of the duodenum between the aorta and SMA leading to duodenal obstruction. Angle between SMA and Aorta becomes less than 25 degrees due to loss of mesenteric fat pad. It is seen in patients with sudden weight loss like in celebrities, AIDS, metastasis. IOC is CT angiography. Treatment is by high calorie diet and surgery is necessary only if conservative management fails. 


Fig: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome. Ba meal showing obstruction in 3rd part of duodenum. 

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1257.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents in OPD with dermatitis and lymphadenopathy. Skull X-ray below. Which of the following medications is most frequently used in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Vinblastine.
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray image showing punched out lytic lesion is s/o LCH. The current standard of care for patients with high-risk LCH is 1 year of therapy with vinblastine/prednisone/mercaptopurine, based on the LCH-III study. 


Reference: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis: A Clinicopathologic Review and Molecular Pathogenetic Update
Published in Seminars in Diagnostic Pathology in 2015, this review provides an in-depth analysis of the clinical, pathological, and molecular aspects of LCH, including recent advancements in understanding its pathogenesis and implications for treatment.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive jaundice, pruritus, and weight loss. You are suspecting cholangiocarcinoma. Where is cholangiocarcinoma most commonly located in such cases?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2. Hilum
Most common site of cholangiocarcinoma is hilum.
  • They are divided into 3 types based  on pathogenesis- Sclerosing, Nodular, Papillary.
  • Clinical Features-
    Painless jaundice is MC symptom of cholangiocarcinoma, followed by pruritus, abdominal pain, weight loss ,fever.
  • Cholangiocarcinomas are tumors arising from bile duct epithelium, most commonly adenocarcinomas.
  • MC gene mutation: K-RAS >p16.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1216.

choices.text: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd intercostal space

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed car accident. He is dyspneic, hypotensive, with tracheal deviation to the left and absent breath sounds on the right. What is the immediate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Insert wide bore needle in 2nd intercostal space.
The clinical scenario says, hypotension, absent breath sounds on right side and tracheal deviation towards left, hence it is a case of right sided tension pneumothorax. First line of management in tension pneumothorax: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd intercostal space in the Mid clavicular line. The urgent treatment for this patient is immediate decompression with a large bore needle in the midclavicular line in the second intercostal gap, followed by IV line insertion and fluid delivery and later chest tube insertion.

Other options:
Tension pneumothorax is an emergency condition and does not require any investigation to confirm the diagnosis or else patient can succumb. Emergency thoracotomy can deteriorate the condition further and can cause hemothorax. 

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 374.

questions.text: A 40 year patient presented with recurrent abdominal pain post cholecystectomy. On USG examination, no significant findings were present. He was discovered to have biliary dyskinesia after additional evaluation by other investigations. Which among the following investigations would not be helpful for diagnosing biliary dyskinesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4. USG
Biliary dyskinesia is a functional bile motility dysfunction without any structural abnormality. Among given options, USG is not done for the diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia as the findings are seen to be normal. The diagnosis of biliary dyskinesia can be made by a HIDA scan (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan) and ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography). Also post surgery follow up will help in identifying these patients as they will present with persistent right upper quadrant pain after cholecystectomy.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1503.

choices.text: Terminate pregnancy because of high risk of infections
Continue pregnancy with use of antibiotics throughout pregnancy

questions.text: A G3P2 who is 30 years old and has amenorrhea for 10 weeks has an intrauterine pregnancy with an intrauterine contraceptive device in place. The IUCD string was discernible at the cervical os during a pelvic exam. The patient wants to carry out the pregnancy. How will you proceed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Remove intrauterine contraceptive device.
If a woman becomes pregnant with an IUD in place, the IUD should be removed if strings are visible or if the IUD is within the cervix, as IUCD can causes fetal anomalies. For women who choose pregnancy termination, the IUD can be removed at the time of surgical abortion and before medication abortion. If the strings of IUCD not visible and women wants to continue pregnancy then leave it in situ, since the risk outweighs the benefits.
IUCD does not increase the chance of infection significantly during pregnancy, thus option 2 and 3 are incorrect. 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 666, 667.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 619.

questions.text: Which is not a component of biophysical profile:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Contraction stress test.
Contraction stress test is NOT a component of Fetal Biophysical Profile (BPP). Contraction test is a separate test that tests fetal heart beat response in respect to uterine contraction. 

Biophysical Profile (BPP)/ Manning score:
 
Component Score 2 Score 0
Nonstress test \(\geq\)2 accelerations \(\geq\)15 beats/min for \(\geq\)15 s in 20-40 min 0 or 1 acceleration in 20-40 min
Fetal breathing \(\geq\)1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting \(\geq\)30 s within 30 min <30 s of breathing in 30 min
Fetal movement \(\geq\)discrete body or limb movements within 30 min <3 discrete movements
Fetal tone \(\geq\)1 episode of extremity extension and subsequent return to flexion 0 extension/flexion events
Amnionic fluid volume Single vertical pocket >2 cm Largest single vertical pocket \(\leq\)2 cm



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 389.

questions.text: The exception to the administration of Anti D prophylaxis from the following conditions is-
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Intra uterine transfusion at 28 weeks
The anti-D vaccine is administered in all cases where there is feto-maternal hemorrhage in a Rh -ve mother.
The anti-D vaccine is not administered during intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Intrauterine transfusion is performed in alloimmunized pregnancies, where the maternal immune system (Rh negative) has been exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood.  The purpose of the anti-D vaccine is to prevent the formation of maternal antibodies against fetal red blood cells, which is already happening in alloimmunized pregnancies. Thus, anti-D vaccine administration is only appropriate for ICT-negative, non-isoimmunized pregnancies. Intrauterine transfusion is considered when the peak systolic velocity of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) >1.5 MoM, when hydrops develops, or when fetal hematocrit levels are critically low. In these cases, the mother already has antibodies against the fetal red blood cells, making anti-D vaccination unnecessary.

Indications for administering anti-D include:

- Pregnancy loss: spontaneous or elective abortion, and ectopic pregnancy.
- Fetal death: at any stage of pregnancy.
- Procedures: such as amniocentesis, chorionic villus sampling, fetal blood sampling, and molar pregnancy evacuation.
- Other situations: antepartum bleeding (including threatened abortion), delivery (vaginal or cesarean), external cephalic version, placental abruption, manual removal of the placenta, and abdominal trauma during pregnancy.

All Rh D-negative women should receive a single dose of 300 mcg of anti-D at 28 weeks of pregnancy, provided that the ICT is negative.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 354-357.

questions.text: A patient with Placenta grade 3, 35+3 weeks pregnancy, AFI=5 and absent end diastolic flow in Doppler; What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Talk with pediatrician and immediate termination

The patient has already crossed 34 weeks and Doppler is showing absent end diastolic flow. Since, lung maturity is attained by 34 weeks, there is no need to wait for dexamethasone coverage.

Management: Immediate TOP by Cesarean section

Stage based classification and management of Termination of Pregnancy in Pregnancy Induced Hypertension:



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 24th edition, Page no 219-222.

choices.text: Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman came in with a 2x3 cm labia majora ulcer that had been present for six months without healing and no palpable lymphadenopathy. Squamous cell cancer is evident after biopsy. The required treatment consists of:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection
According to recent FIGO guidelines, a lesion measuring 2 cm x 3 cm with no palpable lymph nodes is classified as stage 1B vulvar cancer. The recommended management for stage 1B includes a radical partial vulvectomy for the primary tumor. Although lymph nodes may appear normal upon palpation, they can still be affected, so a Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is advised. If the vulvar lesion is more than 2 cm from the midline and located laterally, an ipsilateral lymph node dissection is performed. However, if the lesion is within 2 cm of the midline, a bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is recommended. In this case, the optimal management approach is partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection, given the lesion's characteristics and location.
 



Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 680, 682, 684.

choices.text: Two tablets of high dose OCP, repeated after 24 hours

questions.text: Five days after unprotected sexual contact, a 32-year-old P2L2 woman arrives. What is the next line of action regarding contraception?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Copper IUCD
Woman is already having 2 offspring and IUCD is the best method of Emergency contraception thus Copper IUCD should be given. Moreover only Copper IUCD is effective up to 5 days of unprotected intercourse among the given options. 
The details of various emergency contraceptives is given below:





 Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 400, 412.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains to the OP that her vaginal discharge is green and itchy locally. The cervix seems to be a strawberry upon close inspection. What is the course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: 2. Metronidazole. 
This is a typical case of green vaginal discharge with strawberry cervix suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis. Trichomoniasis is a very common STD caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis (a protozoan parasite). Clinical features itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals. Discomfort when peeing; and A clear, white, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge (i.e., thin discharge or increased volume) with a fishy smell. Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days. Partner is also given the same treatment. Alternative Regimen for Women and Men is Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364, 365.

questions.text: A woman who is 36 weeks pregnant is admitted to your ward. She is depicted in the illustration lying supine during the morning rounds. She complains of faintness and lightheadedness. Which syndrome is pictured below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Inferior vena cava compression syndrome.
Supine hypotensive syndrome/Supine vena cava syndrome (also referred to as inferior vena cava compression syndrome) is caused when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava when a pregnant woman is in a supine position, leading to decreased venous return centrally, thus causing hypotensive symptoms. 
  • Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, nausea, palpitations, and in severe cases, fainting (syncope).
  • Mechanism: Lying supine compresses the IVC, impairing blood flow back to the heart.
  • Risk Factors: More common after 20 weeks of pregnancy; overweight women may be at higher risk.
  • Management: Shift to a left lateral position or elevate the right hip to relieve pressure on the IVC.
  • Prevention: Pregnant women should avoid lying flat on their backs for prolonged periods, especially in the third trimester.
 


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 64.

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Congenital syphilis.
Kassowitz's law states that the risk of vertical transmission of syphilis from an infected, untreated mother decreases as the maternal disease progresses. It is associated hence with congenital syphilis.

 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1207 .

choices.text: Induce labor by artificial rupture of membranes
Sedate the patient by and give phenergan to decrease labor pains
Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions

questions.text: A primigravida who was 38 weeks pregnant arrived in the delivery room with little contractions and labour pains. The cervix is 50% effaced and 2 cm dilated on examination. The patient's blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg and heart rate is 86/min. What action is necessary now?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Observe the patient and wait for increase in uterine contractions
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is in latent phase of labour and vitals are stable, hence wait and watch is the management. 
  • Inducing labor by artificial rupture of membranes (option 1) is not indicated at this point because the cervix is only 2 cm dilated and contractions are minimal.
  • Giving oxytocin to augment labor (option 2) is also not appropriate because labor has not progressed sufficiently.
  • Sedating the patient with phenergan (option 3) is unnecessary and may not be beneficial, as it does not address the underlying labor progression.


Labour is divided into 4 stages.
The first stage (stage of dilatation): From the onset of true labour until the cervix is fully dilated.
It is divided into two phases:

1. The latent phase:
- Starts from onset of labour until the cervix reaches 5 cm dilatation.
- Lasts between 3-8 hours, shorter in multiparous women.
- Contractions occurs at least twice every 10 minutes with each lasting > 20 seconds, not more than moderately strong and are quite well tolerated without analgesia.

2. The active phase:
-From 5 cm-full cervical dilatation (10 cm), here the contractions becomes more frequent and stronger.
- Contractions occurs 3 times every 10 minutes, with each lasting > 40 seconds.
- The cervix should dilate at a rate of 1 cm/hour of faster.
-Last between 2-6 hours.

The duration of the 1st stage of labour in primipara patient range from 6-18 hours (average = 12 hours).
In multiparous women about 2-10 hours (average 5 hours)



Reference: Williams Obstretics, 26th edition, Page no 424-429.

questions.text: Why does a pregnant woman feel lightheaded in the lying, standing for a long time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. IVC Compression. 
Supine hypotensive syndrome (also referred to as inferior vena cava compression syndrome) is caused when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava when a pregnant woman is in a supine position, leading to decreased venous return centrally, causing hypotensive symptoms like light headedness, syncope, etc. That's why pregnant women are advised to lie in left lateral position, as IVC lies in the right side. 


Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 64

questions.text: 30y old female GA - 38+6 days came with labor pains. She was vitally stable. The resident Doctor did PV and found that Fetal head at -3 and membranes are felt as bag of worms beneath the head. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
3. Emergency C section.
Bag of worms on palpation suggestive of cord presentation. The best course of action in patient with Cord presentation is emergency C section. Cord presentation is an emergency condition as if membrane is ruptured it can lead to cord prolapse-> umbilical vessels constriction-> fetal hypoxia and ultimately fetal demise. While preparing for C section patient maybe placed in Exaggerated Sim's position to avoid cord compression.

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page. No- 373, 374.

questions.text: A married couple comes to your clinic, who are unable to conceive for 3 years of unprotected sexual intercourse. You advice the husband for semen analysis. Which of the following factors does the WHO consider as the most important marker of male fertility?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Spermatocyte morphology

Sperm morphology, which assesses the shape and structure of sperm cells, is considered a key indicator of male fertility. Abnormal morphology can impair a sperm’s ability to swim effectively and penetrate the egg, thus affecting fertilization potential. While sperm motility and count are also significant, morphology is often highlighted as a primary marker because it reflects the quality of the sperm more directly in terms of fertilization capability.

Other options:

  1. Spermatocyte count: Important but not as significant as morphology in assessing sperm quality.
  2. Spermatocyte motility: While essential, it is generally secondary to morphology in overall fertility assessments.
  3. Semen volume: This affects total sperm output but does not directly indicate sperm quality or fertility.

WHO semen analysis criteria:





Reference: Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility, 8th edition, Page no 1270.
Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page no 443.

questions.text: 23y old young girl came to Gyne OPD with Irregular menstrual cycles associated with facial hair. She was overweight. All of the following can be advised, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. Anti Androgens.
The Patient's history is suggestive of Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD). Anti Androgens are recommended in PCOD only if patients have no improvement after 6 months with OCPs. First line management of PCOD is weight reduction. OCPs are given to regularize the cycles and metformin is given in case of insulin resistance. 
PCOS diagnosing criteria- Rotterdam criteria requires 2/3:
  • Menstrual abnormalities- Oligo/Amenorrhoea
  • Hyperandrogenism-Hirsutism/acne
  • Ultrasound criteria- USG suggestive of PCOS-12 or more follicles located peripherally 2-9mm and Enlarged ovaries with volume >10mm3.

 * Extra Edge: 
Polycystic ovarian morphology (PCOM) is one criterion for PCOS diagnosis. Earlier sonographic criteria for PCOM included ~12 small cysts (2 to 9 mm in diameter) or an increased ovarian volume (>10 mL) or both per ovary {Fig. 18-10). More recently, follicle number per ovary (FNPO) threshold values have been raised due to improved sonographic imaging resolution. Namely, an FNPO threshold of>20 follicles and/or ovarian volume > 10mL in either ovary has been adopted by ESHRE and ASRM. The AE-PCOS guidelines use the same ovarian volume value but a higher FNPO threshold of ~25 follicles. Notably, criteria do not apply to women taking combination oral contraceptive pills.

Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page. No- 401.

questions.text: What is the double bleb signs in USG depictive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. Amniotic sac and yolk sac.
A double bleb sign is a sonographic feature where there is visualization of a gestational sac containing a yolk sac and amniotic sac giving an appearance of two small bubbles. It occurs in 4.5- 6 weeks of gestation. The embryonic disc is located between the two bubbles. It is an important feature of an intrauterine pregnancy and thus distinguishes a pregnancy from a pseudo-gestational sac or decidual cast cyst. It should not be confused with the double decidual sac sign. 
Other options:

1. Intrauterine two gestation sacs → That would suggest twins, it can have T-sign or Lambda sign. 
3. Ectopic pregnancy → has Ring of Fire sign on doppler. 
4. Heterotopic pregnancy → Rare; shows both intrauterine and ectopic pregnancy, not defined by double bleb. 





 Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 177.

questions.text: A female patient has had lower abdominal pain and amenorrhea for the past eight weeks. A lateral adnexa with a lump and thick endometrium was discovered on USG. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Ectopic pregnancy.
Possible diagnosis in a female with 8 weeks of amenorrhea, pain in the left lower abdomen, and thick endometrium with a mass in the lateral adnexa on an ultrasound is ectopic pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg implants and grows outside the main cavity of the uterus.
 
  • The classic triad is amenorrhea that is followed by pain and vaginal bleeding.
  • With tubal rupture, lower abdominal and pelvic pain is usually severe and frequently described as sharp, stabbing, or tearing. Some degree of vaginal spotting or bleeding is reported by most women with tubal pregnancy.
2,3 and 4 usually don't present with amenorrhea and endometrium in adnexa will not be seen. 

Endometrial findings in TVS:
  1. With ectopic pregnancy, a trilaminar endometrial pattern is characteristic.
  2. First, a pseudosac is a fluid collection between the endometrial layers and conforms to the cavity shape. If a pseudosac is noted, the risk of ectopic pregnancy is increased.
  3. Second, a decidual cyst is identified as an anechoic area lying within the endometrium but remote from the canal and often at the endometrial–myometrial border. Tis may represent early decidual breakdown that precedes cast formation.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 221-223.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for screening cancers in females?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Office Endometrial aspirate is not a screening but a diagnostic test for cancer endometrium.
For women with genetic mutations, ovarian cancer screening using a combination of CA-125 and TVS should be done. Endometrial cancer screening is not recommended in asymptomatic general population. Only in case of postmenopausal bleeding, TVS is done to access the endometrial thickness. 


CANCER SCREENING: 




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 435.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 299.

choices.text: 8 contractions in 60 mins with cervical changes

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 32 weeks gestation presents with lower abdominal cramps and backache. You suspect, her to be a case of preterm labour. Which of the following findings does not support the diagnosis of preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Cervix directly posteriorly. 
In case of preterm labour, cervix will be directed anteriorly. 

Criteria for preterm labor (Herron's)
Regular uterine contraction (>4contractions in 20 minutes or 8 contractions in 60 mins) and Gestational age 20-37 weeks with one of the following 
1.  More than 80% effaced cervix 
2. Cervical dilation > 1cm
3. Progressive cervical changes
 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 294,295 .

questions.text: A 15-year-old female patient with primary amenorrhea arrives at the OPD for consultation. Her breast development appears to be normal upon evaluation. Genitalia on the outside are typical. A 5 alpha reductase deficiency diagnosis is made .What is the classification of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Male pseudohermaphrodite.
The genetic (XY chromosome) and gonadal sex (testis) is male, hence the person is male but the genital sex is female, hence the person is a male pseudohermaphrodite. 
Other options:
1. Female pseudohermaphrodite is the vice versa of male pseudohermaphrodite.
3. True hermaphrodite refers to the presence of ovo-testis. 
4. Concealed sex refers to a person concealing his/her sex for certain gains. 




Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 108, 114.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Answer : 3. Anovulation.
Puberty menorrhagia is most commonly caused by anovulatory cycles.

Anovulatory cycles lead to:
- Unopposed estrogen stimulation
- Endometrial hyperplasia
- Prolonged and heavy menstrual bleeding

Other potential causes include:
1. Endocrine dysfunction:
- Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
- Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism
2. Hematological disorders:
- Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
- Von Willebrand‘s disease
- Leukemia
3. Pelvic tumors:
- Uterine fibroids
- Sarcoma botryoides
- Estrogen-producing ovarian tumors
4. Pregnancy complications:
- Miscarriage (abortion)

Treatment:
1. Initial management:
- Reassurance and psychological support
- Rest and correction of anemia
2. Pharmacological treatment:
- In refractory cases, progestogens such as medroxyprogesterone acetate or norethisterone (5 mg, three times daily) are administered until the bleeding stops. Typically, bleeding is controlled within 3–7 days, and the medication is continued for 21 days. Normal cycles usually resume after 2–3 courses of treatment.
3. Emergency management:
- In cases of severe bleeding, conjugated equine estrogen (20–40 mg IV) can be given every 6–8 hours. Once bleeding is controlled, combined oral contraceptive pills are introduced.

Outcome:
Regular menstrual cycles are expected to establish once the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis matures.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 43,44 .

questions.text: Patient of middle age has had chest pain for the last three hours. Trop T = 14 ng/dl, patient's ECG demonstrates ST segment depression and T wave inversion. Vitals remain constant. Which course of treatment is recommended for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Aspirin with LMWH.
The patient is suffering from NSTEMI (Non-ST elevation MI) since Trop T is elevated but ST is not elevated. Aspirin with heparin can be used for the initial treatment for this patient. Primary PCI is not done. Thrombolysis in NSTEMI can cause microvascular occlusion and can further worsen the condition. 
Acute coronary syndrome is divided into two main groups: 
1. ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
2. Non-ST-Elevation Acute Coronary Syndrome (NSTE-ACS)
NSTE-ACS is further categorized into:
- NSTEMI (where myocyte necrosis is present and cardiac troponins are elevated)
- Unstable Angina (where myocyte necrosis is absent and cardiac troponins are not elevated)

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS relies on the following criteria:
- Severe chest discomfort accompanied by at least one of these three features. 
- Occurrence at rest or with minimal exertion, lasting more than 10 minutes
- Recent onset
- Crescendo pattern

Additionally, the ECG may show:
- ST segment depression
- T wave inversion
- Elevated cardiac troponins in the case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:
  • To alleviate pain and discomfort, the initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (administered only if arterial oxygen saturation is below 90%).
  • Antithrombotic therapy involves both antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications:- Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) plus one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, Clopidogrel, or Prasugrel).
- Anticoagulation: Options include Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, Fondaparinux, or Bivalirudin.
  • An early invasive strategy is recommended for stabilized patients at high risk for coronary events (based on TIMI, GRACE, or HEART scores). This includes diagnostic coronary angiography within 2-72 hours of presentation, followed by revascularization (either percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2047, 2051.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer had a 16.4 mmol/L serum calcium level when they were first seen. What will be the initial management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and furosemide

The given clinical scenario is of hypercalcemia due to squamous cell carcinoma of lungs. I.V. fluids and diuretics are the first-line treatments for managing hypercalcemia in an emergency.

Even though IV bisphosphonates are the preferred medication for treating malignant hypercalcemia, their activity doesn't begin for at least 3–4 days, thus they are useless in an urgent situation. Hemodialysis is done only in case of renal failure. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173, 3183.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents for routine follow-up. His labs show early signs of diabetic nephropathy with microalbuminuria. Which of the following medications is beneficial in preventing microalbuminuria and slowing progression of renal damage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Finerenone.
The following drugs are beneficial in preventing microalbuminuria
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors / Angiotensin receptor blockers - These medications appear to slow the rate of decline of kidney function by reducing the intraglomerular hyperfiltration and hypertension.
  • Finerenone - It is a non steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist which decreases proteinuria.
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors - These drugs inhibit sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 in the proximal convoluted tubule. By increasing Nacl delivery to the thick ascending limb, gliflozins trigger tubuloglomerular feedback and thereby increase preglomerular vascular resistance and decrease glomerular hypertension. This contributes to the effectiveness of gliflozins to prevent diabetic kidney disease.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2316, 2319.

questions.text: What is a patient's urine analysis most likely to show if they have hematuria and hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Isomorphic RBCs.
Urine analysis of a patient with hematuria and hypercalciuria is most likely to reveal isomorphic RBCs. 
Hypercalciuria is a cause of non-glomerular hematuria. RBCs from a non-glomerular source more closely resemble peripheral blood on microscopy, with isomorphic RBCs and absence of casts, since they are not distorted. 








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2280, 2304.

questions.text: A 9 year boy comes with sexual maturity rating 5, height age > chronological age, hyperpigmentation and short stature. His blood pressure measured 200/110mmHg. Which of the following enzymes deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. 11 beta hydroxylase.
The given clinical scenario of precocious puberty(SMR grading of 5 in a 9 year old boy) with height age> chronological age with short stature and increased blood pressure 180/110 suggests 11 beta hydroxylase deficient variant of CAH.11 Beta hydroxylase deficiency is a variant of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) causing increased aldosterone and testosterone activity with reduced cortisol levels.

Other options: 

1. 21α-hydroxylase deficiency → Most common CAH, but usually has hypotension, not HTN
3. Cholesterol side chain cleavage enzyme deficiency → Impaired synthesis of all steroids, presents with ambiguous genitalia and adrenal insufficiency
4. 3β-HSD deficiency → Ambiguous genitalia in both sexes, no hypertension


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 2972,2976-77.

questions.text: The H-reflex can be used to diagnose
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. S1 radiculopathy.
The H-reflex (or Hoffmann's reflex) is used primarily to diagnose S1 radiculopathy.
  • A H-reflex is a spinal reflex that involves both sensory and motor fibers. It's a sensitive test that can be used to assess radiculopathy.
  • During an H-reflex test, the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa is stimulated to elicit a monosynaptic S1 reflex response.
  • It assesses the integrity of the S1 nerve root by measuring the electrical response of the muscle following stimulation of the sensory nerve.
  • In evaluating radiculopathy, a unilateral absent H reflex or a side-to-side latency difference greater than 2.0 ms supports a diagnosis of an S1 radiculopathy




Reference: Alrowayeh, Hesham N, and Mohamed A Sabbahi. “H-reflex amplitude asymmetry is an earlier sign of nerve root involvement than latency in patients with S1 radiculopathy.” BMC research notes vol. 4 102. 5 Apr. 2011, doi:10.1186/1756-0500-4-102. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3078869/

questions.text: 50y old male was diagnosed to have Cardiac failure. Which among the following will delay the progression of heart failure in this man?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. Enalapril.
ACE inhibitors are used in Heart failure as they prevent progression of disease and prevent Cardiac Remodeling.


*Extra Edge: 

Left ventricular (LV) remodeling (ie, enlargement and functional deterioration occurring over time) is among the main mechanisms of progression in heart failure (HF). LV dilatation and dysfunction are major negative prognostic markers in patients with HF. Treatments that are effective in limiting or even reversing this process can be expected to provide clinical benefit. Changes in LV dimensions rather than in ejection fraction should be used to monitor remodeling. Ejection fraction can be influenced by transient loading conditions and by agents that stimulate contractility at the expense of increased oxygen demand, whereas dimensional changes probably reflect structural modifications occurring in the myocardium. The neurohormonal antagonists that have been demonstrated to reduce mortality and morbidity in HF (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors [ACE], beta-blockers, angiotensin receptor blockers, and aldosterone antagonists) are also able to inhibit or reverse remodeling. In reverse remodeling, beta-blockers appear to be superior to the other classes of drugs, with a stronger correlation between dose and effect, but it must be remembered that they have been tested as an addition to background therapy that may include ACE inhibitors. 

Reference: Frigerio M, Roubina E. Drugs for left ventricular remodeling in heart failure. Am J Cardiol. 2005 Dec 19;96(12A):10L-18L. doi: 10.1016/j.amjcard.2005.09.060. Epub 2005 Oct 5. PMID: 16399088.

questions.text: A patient with known diabetes and hypertension was discovered on the side of the road in the morning, unconscious, with a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute and a bilateral plantar extensor response. What should we do as soon as possible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Check blood glucose level.
In the given clinical scenario the diabetic and hypertensive patient is unconscious, having tachycardia and Babinski sign is positive, which points to the diagnosis of Hypoglycemic coma. Thus, checking blood glucose level is the immediate next step of management. 

Clinical features of Hypoglycemia:
  • Neuroglycopenic manifestations of hypoglycemia are the direct result of central nervous system glucose deprivation.
  • These features include behavioral changes, confusion, fatigue, seizure, hunger, loss of consciousness, cardiac arrhythmias, and, if hypoglycemia is severe, death.
  • Neurogenic (or autonomic) manifestations of hypoglycemia result from the perception of physiologic changes caused by the central nervous system–mediated sympathoadrenal discharge that is triggered by hypoglycemia causing tachycardia and sweating. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3129, 3130.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with muscle weakness and ECG changes showing peaked T waves. His serum potassium is 7.2 mEq/L. Which of the following medications is not used in the emergency management of acute hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Intravenous magnesium sulphate.
Intravenous magnesium sulfate is not used in the emergency management of acute hyperkalemia. It is used in management of Torsades de pointes. 

Step-wise management of Acute Hyperkalemia:
1. IV Calcium gluconate- stabilizes the myocardium and prevents cardiac arrythmias. 
2. Salbutamol nebulization- Causes K+ entry into the cells.
3. Glucose- Insulin- Insulin cause glucose and K+ entry into the cells. Glucose is given to prevent hypoglycemia. 
4. Furosemide- Increase K+ excretion through urine. 
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: What does high calcium intake can lead to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Milk-Alkali syndrome
High calcium intake can lead to the development of Milk-Alkali Syndrome. This condition occurs due to excessive consumption of calcium-containing products, such as milk or calcium supplements, combined with excessive intake of absorbable alkali (such as antacids containing calcium carbonate). The syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypercalcemia (high levels of calcium in the blood), metabolic alkalosis (high pH of the blood), and kidney dysfunction.

The other options listed are not directly associated with high calcium intake.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173.

questions.text: 65-year-old man experiencing palpitations and a sudden, excruciating discomfort. What are the best cardiac indicators with a high sensitivity and specificity at two hours after myocardial injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : 2. Troponin T
Best cardiac marker/markers with high sensitivity and specificity 2-4 hours post myocardial injury is Troponin T. It is used in the given case because it rises very fast post attack and is very specific for myocardial infarction, unlike CK MB which may also rise in case of muscle injury. The other markers take more time to rise and BNP is also raised in Heart Failure. 






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2055.

questions.text: Which artery is involved in patient with Wallenberg Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Vertebral Artery.
Vertebral artery>PICA is involved in Lateral Medullary or Wallenberg syndrome. The following tracts are affected in Lateral Medullary syndrome Nucleus of Trigeminal nerve, Inferior Cerebellar peduncle, Lateral Spinothalamic tract ,IX and X CN ,Vestibular nucleus ,Descending Sympathetic tract.

Other options:
 

2. Anterior Spinal Artery: This artery supplies the medial medulla. Its occlusion causes medial medullary syndrome.
3. Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA): This artery supplies the lateral cerebral hemisphere, especially the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes.
4. Basilar Artery: While it supplies much of the brainstem, its occlusion typically causes more extensive brainstem syndromes, like locked-in syndrome. 





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page. No-285, 315.

choices.text: One dose of low molecular weight heparin subcutaneously followed by dual antiplatelet therapy

questions.text: A patient with aortic valve disease who also had right hemiparesis was admitted. What steps will you take to prevent further strokes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. Anticoagulant only.
In the given clinical scenario the patient is suffering from embolic stroke due to valvular pathology, hence anticoagulants like warfarin should be given to the patient to prevent further stroke. 
Antiplatelets are used in atherosclerotic stroke but not embolic stroke. Co-administration of antiplatelet and anticoagulant is not recommended as it increases the bleeding tendencies. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3338.

questions.text: All are true about Renal tubular acidosis in children except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Type IV- Metabolic acidosis and Hypokalemia.
Type IV is associated with Metabolic acidosis with Hyperkalemia. Other RTAs are associated with Hypokalemia. Below is an important table of differences between different RTAs



Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 493-495.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain and was treated with some medication. 3 hours post-treatment with this medication - the lady developed palpitations and respiratory distress. BP is 116/76 mm Hg, spO2 98% under room air and ECG is shown below. What treatment will you give the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. MgSO4.
Torsade de pointes is the suspected diagnosis based on the patients' ECG.
