Long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that result in Torsade de pointes can be effectively treated and prevented with IV MgSO4. Defibrillation should be started right away if the patient is unstable. The ECG presented indicates wide QRS complex tachycardia with varying QRS amplitudes, suggesting torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the preferred treatment is intravenous MgSO. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) is characterized by continuously changing QRS morphology. When it occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired QT interval prolongation, it is known as torsades de pointes. Patients may experience near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest. IV MgSO is very effective for both treating and preventing recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that can trigger torsades de pointes. If magnesium treatment is ineffective, an infusion of isoproterenol or pacing at a rate of 100-120 depolarizations per minute generally suppresses VT recurrences. In cases where the patient is hemodynamically unstable, immediate defibrillation is necessary.
Amoidarone can be used in the treatment of monomorphic VT, post- MI. Calcium can be used only if hypocalcemia is the precipitating factor for torsades de pointes, but is never the first line management. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1911, 1923, 1924.

questions.text: A landmark discovery in neuropharmacology involved identifying a specific disease characterized by a significant reduction in a single neurotransmitter, leading to a major breakthrough in understanding its pathophysiology and treatment. Which of the following conditions was the first to be associated with a documented decrease in a single neurotransmitter?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Parkinson's disease.
Parkinson's disease was the first disease where single neurotransmitter reduction was described in the pathophysiology of the disease. It is caused due to degeneration  of dopaminergic neurons in the Substantia nigra.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3387.

questions.text: A patient presents to your OPD with extensive chronic plaque psoriasis. You decide to give a calcineurin inhibitor. Which of the following medications is a calcineurin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Cyclosporine
The immune system's T cells are activated by the calcium and calmodulin-dependent serine/threonine protein phosphatase known as calcineurin. It dephosphorylates the transcription factor nuclear factor of activated T cell, cytoplasmic (NFATc), activating it. The nucleus is where the activated NFATc is translocated after which it increases the expression of IL-2, which in turn derives the development and differentiation of T cells. A class of medications known as calcineurin inhibitors, which includes cyclosporine, pimecrolimus, and tacrolimus, target calcineurin.

Other options:

2. Methotrexate→ A folate antagonist that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, used in psoriasis.
3. Azathioprine→ Purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis, used in psoriasis.
4. Mycophenolate mofetil → Inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase — used in autoimmune diseases, but not specifically in psoriasis.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 937, 939.

questions.text:
A patient has been admitted to the emergency room with a possible acid-base disorder. Which of the following is most likely to help with the diagnosis?
(i) pH of arterial blood
(ii) pH of venous blood
(iii) pO2 of venous blood
(iv) pCO2 of venous blood
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. (i), (ii). Arterial and Venous pH can be used to identify acid-base disorders.

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is considered the gold standard for evaluating oxygen and acid-base status. Venous blood gas (VBG) analysis is increasingly being adopted as an alternative to ABG, as the difference in pH between VBG and ABG is clinically insignificant (with arterial pH generally 0.03 higher than venous pH), rendering venous pH values acceptable. 

Other options:  
 
  • Option 3: The pO2 values exhibit a notable difference, as arterial pO2 (normal 95 mmHg) is usually 55 mmHg higher than venous pO2 (normal 40 mmHg), which makes venous pO2 values unacceptable.  
  • Option 4: Venous pCO2 (normal range 41 to 51 mmHg) values show a significant discrepancy from arterial pCO2 (normal range 35 to 45 mmHg), varying by 5 to 15 mmHg, thus rendering venous pCO2 values unacceptable.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 360.

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology.14th edition, Page no 1085.

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic with respiratory acidosis

questions.text: ABG findings of a person presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting are as follows. pH 7.30, HCO3-18, Na 135, K+ 5, Cl- 92. Blood glucose is 490 mg/dL. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
1. High anion gap metabolic acidosis.
In the given clinical scenario the pH in the given ABG is less than 7.35 so it is acidotic, and bicarbonate  of 18 (Normal value = 22-25) is suggestive of metabolic acidosis. Anion gap is given by the following formula Anion gap = Serum [Na+ – (Cl– + HCO3–)]. The anion gap of the given ABG is 135- (92+18)=25 which is greater than 12 and is suggestive of high anion gap metabolic acidosis.



Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 359, 367.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU for septic shock due to pneumonia. She has been on mechanical ventilation for the past 14 days. As her sepsis improves, the medical team notices she is unable to wean off the ventilator. On examination, she is awake but has generalized weakness, most prominently in the limbs, with preserved cranial nerve function. There is no sensory level or sphincter involvement. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
1. Neurological recovery is complete
2. Sequential nerve demyelination followed by inflammatory myopathy during course of disease
3. Cranial nerves are involved more commonly than peripheral nerve
4. Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause it
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause it.
The clinical scenario is of diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation in a case of critical illness myoneuropathy.
Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) or critical illness myopathy (CIM) are the most common causes of weakness in critically ill patients in the ICU due to prolonged neuromuscular blockade. Both CIM and CIP develop as a complication of sepsis and multiple organ failure. They usually present as an inability to wean a patient from a ventilator. Serum creatine kinase (CK) levels are usually normal; an elevated serum CK level indicates CIM rather than CIP. In CIP, nerve conduction studies show that motor and sensory studies are absent or have significantly reduced amplitudes, whereas sensory studies are relatively preserved in CIM. Improvement takes weeks in mild cases and months in severe cases. Over 50% of patients have reported complete recovery. In more severe cases, however, recovery may be incomplete or may not occur at all.

Other options: 
1. Neurological recovery is not complete in all cases, as in severe cases recovery is not complete. 

2. Sequential nerve demyelination followed by inflammatory myopathy- This is not the pathophysiology. CIPNM involves axonal degeneration (not demyelination) and primary myopathy, often occurring simultaneously, not sequentially.

3. Cranial nerves are involved more commonly than peripheral nerve is incorrect. Cranial nerve involvement is rare. Limb and respiratory muscles (especially the diaphragm) are more commonly affected.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3490.

questions.text: A patient with satellite skin lesion presents to the hospital. He also has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The treatment best suited would be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. Multi drug therapy x 6 months.
It is a case of Leprosy with 1 hypo-pigmented Lesion and 1 thickened Nerve making it a paucibacillary leprosy case and the treatment would be multi-drug therapy for 6 months. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 366 .

choices.text: Very height weight for age (below -3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), by visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema
Very low weight for age (below -2 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), only
Visible severe stunting, or presence of nutritional edema
Very low weight for height (below -3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), by visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his mother due to poor weight gain and frequent illness. On examination, the child appears visibly wasted and with a distended abdomen. Based on Indian guidelines what is the definition of severe acute malnutrition (SAM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Very low weight for height (below -3 Z scores of the mean WHO standards for growth), by visible severe wasting, or presence of nutritional edema.
Severe wasting, that is very low weight for age occurs not decrease in height for age (stunting) because SAM is an acute process. Reduction in height for age occurs in chronic malnutrition. 

Given below is the SAM criteria: 



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 755.

choices.text: Assertion and Reason is true, Reason is the correct explanation of A
Assertion is true, Reason is not explanation for Assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false

questions.text:
Assertion: WHO recommends Typhoid Vaccine for Disaster management is Endemic areas
Reason: Typhoid vaccination is a cost effective way of disaster control.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Both are false .
WHO recommends use of measles vaccine and Vitamin A prophylaxis during disaster management due to commonly encountered outbreak of acute gastroenteritis. Since typhoid outbreak doesn't usually occur after disaster, typhoid vaccination is not a cost effective way of disaster control.   
Typhoid Vaccine Features: 
  • Reduction in the incidence and severity of infection.
  • Groups at risk of infection include school children or hospital staff, Household interactions, Visitors to endemic regions and large religious gatherings.
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 924.

questions.text: The ward sister has been instructed to keep three buckets- black, red and yellow in the ward for garbage control. What would be placed inside a black bucket?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. Wrapper of hand gloves.
Wrappers of hand gloves are among the general hospital waste hence disposed in black. General hospital waste constitute 85% of total hospital waste. Gloves are plastic waste hence disposed in red. Soiled linen are kept in yellow bin. Mattress is not a general hospital waste, they are not disposed by biomedical waste management, they are disposed by separate channel. 



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 919.

questions.text: You work at PHC as a medical officer. Transferring 50 patients with anti-hypertensive needs from the periphery to your PHC. 40 persons must take amlodipine (5mg PO). Amlodipine should not be used by 10 persons, thus they must begin using Lisinopril instead (10mg PO).PHC will receive drugs once each month. In total, how many medications will you order, and what will the reorder factor be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. 3000, 2. 
You can determine how many of each item you need to order by using the reorder factor, which is a numerical value. 
It calls for keeping enough product on hand to meet demand until your next reorder, as well as an extra buffer to guard against unforeseen increases in demand or delays in delivery or pickup. 
If supplies are supplied once a month, the reorder factor is 2 (1 x 2 = 2).
If supplies are delivered every three months (3 x 2 = 6), the reorder factor is 6.
If supplies are delivered every six months (6 x 2 = 12), the reorder factor is 12.

Tablet Amlodipine:40 x 1 x 30= 1200 tablets are required in a month
Tablet Lisinopril: 10 x 1 x 30 = 300 tablets are required in a month.
Total number of drugs required combined: 1200+ 300 = 1500 tablets. 
Reorder factor for supplies delivered once a month is 2.
1500 x 2 = 3000 tablets has to be ordered in a month.

 


Online reference: 9. Rettig RA, Earley LE, and Merrill RA Editors. Food and Drug Administration Advisory Committees in Committee to Study the Use of Advisory Committees, Institute of Medicine;1992.

questions.text:
Calculate the Kappa statistics for the following data comparing IGRA and Mantoux test. The table provided is as follows:
IGRA (+) IGRA (-) Total
Mantoux (+) 80 40 120
Mantoux (-) 20 60 80
100 100 200
questions.solution:
Kappa (κ) = (Po – Pe) / (1 – Pe)

Where:

  • Po = Observed agreement

  • Pe = Expected agreement by chance

Given Table:

IGRA (+) IGRA (-) Total
Mantoux (+) 80 40 120
Mantoux (-) 20 60 80
Total 100 100 200

Step 1: Observed Agreement (Po)

Observed agreement = (80 + 60) / 200 = 140 / 200 = 0.70

Step 2: Expected Agreement (Pe)

Calculate chance agreement for each category:

  • For IGRA (+) & Mantoux (+):
    = (Row total for Mantoux +) × (Column total for IGRA +) / Total
    = (120 × 100) / 200 = 60

  • For IGRA (−) & Mantoux (−):
    = (80 × 100) / 200 = 40

So, Expected agreement = (60 + 40) / 200 = 100 / 200 = 0.50

Step 3: Kappa Calculation

κ=0.70−0.501−0.50=0.200.50=0.4\kappa = \frac{0.70 - 0.50}{1 - 0.50} = \frac{0.20}{0.50} = 0.4κ=1−0.500.70−0.50=0.500.20=0.4

Correct Answer: 3. 0.4




Reference: McHugh, Mary L. “Interrater reliability: the kappa statistic.” Biochemia medica vol. 22,3 (2012): 276-82. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3900052/

questions.text: Tuberculin testing is a low-cost and widely available test. Which of the following scenarios it has a high failure rate in test interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. High percentage of immunized people.
The Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) or Mantoux test detects a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction to purified protein derivative (PPD) from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. However, its interpretation can be problematic in certain scenarios.

Why TST has high failure (false-positive) rate in immunized individuals:

In countries with a high percentage of BCG-vaccinated individuals, many people will test positive on TST even if they do not have active or latent TB. This is due to cross-reactivity between PPD and BCG vaccine antigens, or exposure to non-tuberculous (environmental) mycobacteria. 
Hence, it reduces the specificity of the test and increases the false-positive rate, making interpretation difficult.

Other options:

2. HIV cases are less → In this case, TST performs better, as immunosuppression in HIV can lead to false negatives. 
3. High prevalence of disease→ TST may be more useful here because prior exposure is common. 
4. Environmental mycobacterium infections are less→ Less cross-reactivity = better specificity = easier interpretation



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 216.

questions.text: Chronic liver disease is classified into Child–Pugh class A to C, employing the added score from above. Class A: 5–6, B: 7–9, C: 10–15. This is …………scale:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. Ordinal.
Using the additional score from above, chronic liver disease is categorized into Child-Pugh class A to C.
Class A: 5-6,
Class B: 7-9,
Class C: 10-15.
This is an ordinal scale since the data may be organized in a meaningful order, but the distance between them cannot be determined.


Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 3.

choices.text: 20 mg of elemental iron to all 2–5-year old children biweekly for an entire year.
100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid to women in the reproductive age group weekly throughout the reproductive age.
100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid to pregnant women biweekly for an entire year.
20 mg of elemental iron and 100 micrograms of folic acid to 2–5-year old children weekly for an entire year.

questions.text: Which of these drug regimens complies with the National Iron Plus Program's recommendations for treating anaemia due to iron deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. 100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid to women in the reproductive age group weekly throughout the reproductive age.
100 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid to women in the reproductive age group weekly throughout the reproductive age. Now 60mg of elemental iron is used due to similar absorption and lesser side effects. Under this program, pregnant women have to be given a total of 180 days of Iron therapy everyday. For children aged 6months -5 years, 20mg elemental iron is given with 100 micrograms of folic acid biweekly till 5 years of age.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 533.

questions.text: A researcher is conducting a statistical analysis to compare different groups in a clinical trial. She plans to analyze the relationship between continuous variables, compare the means of different groups, and assess variance within those groups. While reviewing her statistical toolbox, she considers using Student's t-test, ANOVA, Pearson correlation test, and the Friedman test for different parts of her analysis. Which of the following is a non-parametric test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Friedman test.
Friedman test among the following is a non-parametric test. The Friedman test is the non-parametric alternative to the one-way ANOVA with repeated measures. It is used to test for differences between groups when the dependent variable being measured is ordinal.



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 34.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding screw feed technology is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. Ideal for pathological waste.
Screw-Feed Technology is suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps. But it should not be used to process pathological, cytotoxic, or radioactive waste.
Screw-Feed Technology:
• A non-burn, dry thermal disinfection process that reduces waste by 80% in volume and 20-35% in weight.
• Suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps. 
• Should not be used to process pathological, cytotoxic, or radioactive waste.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 917.

questions.text:
A public health student is reviewing global indicators used to measure the overall development and well-being of populations. While studying composite indices published by international bodies like the United Nations Development Program(UNDP), she comes across the Human Development Index (HDI). She learns that HDI is widely used to rank countries based on their human development status. Which of the following best represents the components used to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI)?
1. Life expectancy at age one, literacy and infant mortality
2. Freedom, spice and right to express oneself
3. Life expectancy at birth, infant mortality and quality of life
4. Life expectancy at birth, knowledge and decent standard of living
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 4. Life expectancy at birth, knowledge and decent standard of living.
The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic of life expectancy, education, and income indices used to rank countries into four tiers of human development.
 
It consists of three parameters- 
  • A long and healthy life: Life expectancy at birth 
  • Education index: Mean years of schooling and Expected years of schooling
  • A decent standard of living: GNI per capita in purchasing power parity of US dollars. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: 200 individuals with a normal distribution make up the population. How many people would make up one SD?
questions.solution:
In this case ,136 people would be included in 1 SD.
The question mentions normal distribution, that is bell shaped distribution. 
Because 1 SD contains 68.3% of total samples.
0.68*200= 136.  
 
  • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 standard deviations of the mean
  • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 standard deviations of the mean.
  • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 standard deviations of the mean



Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 11.

choices.text: Cases are spread over 5 or more cities
At least one or more laboratory confirmed H1N1 case

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to a tertiary care hospital with high-grade fever, dry cough, and myalgia. He reports that several coworkers have developed similar symptoms over the past week. At what point is a pandemic of H1N1 suspected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 2. Cases are spread over 5 or more cities.

The Government of India (Ministry of Health) and WHO guidelines state that a pandemic phase may be suspected when: “Cases are reported in 5 or more cities, possibly within a short span of time, especially with laboratory confirmation.” Pandemic takes an account of clustered spread and also geographic spread. 

Other options: 

1. Cases occur within 2 weeks period-> This may indicate a local outbreak or cluster, but without wider geographic spread, it does not qualify as a pandemic suspicion.
 3. At least one or more laboratory-confirmed H1N1 case-> A lab-confirmed case is important for diagnosis, but a single case alone does not fulfill the epidemiological criteria to suspect a pandemic.
4. 25 or more people are affected -> While this may represent a moderate-sized outbreak, it does not qualify as a pandemic suspicion unless there is significant geographic spread.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 108.

questions.text: What is the vector in the given disease cycle:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Hard tick.
Vector in the given disease is hard tick.

Difference between hard and soft tick can be made by the help of following features:
  • Scutellum seen on the back is small in case of hard tick.
  • When seen from above head is visible in hard tick but not visible in case of soft tick.


Hard tick 

Soft tick- head not visible 

Trombiculid mite


Louse- has claws
 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 347.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the empty thecal sac sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Arachnoiditis.
Arachnoiditis is defined as inflammation within the subarachnoid space which leads to formation of organizing exudates and thereby, permanent intradural adhesions. The "Empty Thecal Sac Sign" is a radiological finding seen on MRI, especially T2-weighted sagittal images, where, the thecal sac appears "empty" because the nerve roots are clumped together and stuck to the periphery of the dural sac. 
Causes:
  • Most common cause-Iatrogenic 
  • Accidental trauma 
  • Spinal subarachnoid hemorrhage 
  • Intradural infection 

Radiographic features- MRI is the most sensitive modality to delineate the findings. 

Three morphological patterns of arachnoiditis described on the basis of imaging are: 
  • Type I: nerve roots clumped together and distorted
  • Type II: nerve roots adherent to the theca resulting in an empty thecal sac sign
  • Type III: nerve roots and theca clumped together into a single soft tissue mass centrally within the spinal canal 
The empty thecal sac sign or empty sac sign is when the thecal sac appears empty on MRI of the lumbar spine, best seen on T2-weighted images. If the empty thecal sac sign is present, a diagnosis of adhesive arachnoiditis can be made.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 1371.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought in with complaints of photophobia and bilateral proptosis along with eye watering. Which medical diagnosis is more likely from the clinical history and the clinical image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Congenital glaucoma.
Watering of eyes along with bilateral proptosis and photophobia and corneal haze as given in the image, in a 2 year old child is suggestive of congenital glaucoma.
It is seen between birth and the age of 3-4 years.
Clinical features:
The affected eye is enlarged with a hazy cornea.
Increased size of eyeball (Buphthalmos).
Photophobia is the earliest symptoms due to corneal edema
It should be noted that the earliest sign is Corneal Haze (Ground glass appearance)
Watering of eyes
At a later stage, due to rupture of Descemet's membrane, more discrete corneal opacities are seen
Blue eyes due to scleral thinning.
Management: 
  • Goniotomy is done if there is no corneal haze.
  • Trabeculotomy+ Trabeculectomy is done if there is corneal haze.
  • Drainage devices are used in refractory cases. 


 
Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1106, 1107.

questions.text: Ocriplasmin is a recombinant protease and it is used to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. Vitreomacular adhesion. 

Ocriplasmin is a recombinant protease enzyme that breaks down proteins like laminin and fibronectin in the vitreoretinal interface. It is FDA-approved for the treatment of symptomatic vitreomacular adhesion (VMA) and vitreomacular traction (VMT).

Mechanism of action: 

  • Ocriplasmin enzymatically cleaves the protein matrix that causes the vitreous to remain abnormally adherent to the macula.

  • This leads to pharmacologic vitreolysis, allowing for posterior vitreous detachment.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 613, 614.

choices.text: Probe can be passed underneath the pterygium at the limbs
Elastotic degeneration with distortion of Descemet's membrane

questions.text: A 45-year-old construction worker from a tropical region presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of a painless, triangular, fleshy growth on the nasal side of his right eye that has slowly enlarged over the past year. He reports no vision changes but feels some mild irritation and redness, especially when outdoors. He has a history of chronic sun exposure without consistent use of eye protection. On slit-lamp examination, a wing-shaped fibrovascular growth is seen encroaching onto the cornea. Which of the following is correct regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. Bare sclera technique has 30-80% recurrence.
Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea.
The Bare sclera technique refers to the surgical removal of the pterygium without any additional tissue graft or covering. This technique has been associated with a relatively high recurrence rate ranging from 30% to 80%, making it a less preferred option for pterygium surgery. Amniotic membrane transplant is done to reduce the recurrence. 

Other options:
  • Probe test helps to differentiate pterygium from pseudopterygium. Probe test is negative in pterygium i.e Probe cannot be passed underneath the pterygium. (Option 1)
  • Pterygium is primarily associated with long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight, not infrared radiation. (Option 2) 
  • This statement describes pinguecula, not pterygium. Pinguecula is a condition characterized by yellowish conjunctival deposits that do not extend onto the cornea. It is associated with elastotic degeneration and can cause distortion of Descemet's membrane. (Option 4)


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 206, 207.
Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 89-91.

questions.text: A male 7-year-old child is seen with normal vision in his right eye (6/6) and the ability to see hand movements close to the face in his left eye. On fundoscopy, the left eye had a retinal detachment, subretinal yellow exudates, and telangiectatic vessels, while the right eye was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Coats' disease .
The given features are suggestive of Coat’s disease, it’s an idiopathic retinal telangiectasia, generally of onset in early childhood. It is associated with intraretinal and subretinal exudation, and frequently exudative retinal detachment, without signs of vitreoretinal traction.

Definition: a localized, congenital, retinal vascular disorder consisting of abnormal telangiectatic segments of blood vessels that result in leakage.

Key Features: 
• Retinal telangiectasia.
• Retinal capillary nonperfusion.
• dilated intercapillary spaces.
• Lipid exudate.
• subretinal fluid.

Associated Features:
• Usually unilateral.
• Male predominance.
• Fibrovascular macular scars.
• Leucocoria.
• Rare systemic associations, especially muscular dystrophies.



Other options: 

2. Sympathetic Ophthalmitis- This is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis that typically occurs after trauma or surgery to one eye. 
3. Familial Exudative Vitreoretinopathy (FEVR)- FEVR is a hereditary disorder that affects the development of retinal blood vessels. It typically presents bilaterally, and there is often a family history of vision problems. While it can cause exudation and retinal detachment, the unilateral presentation and lack of family history make it less likely in this case.
4. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP)- ROP occurs in premature infants, particularly those born before 31 weeks of gestation or with low birth weight. It is also usually bilateral. Since this is a 7-year-old child with no history of prematurity provided and a unilateral retinal finding, ROP is not a likely diagnosis here.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 562.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man arrived with right eye pain and watering that had been present for 36 hours. A 3 x 2 cm corneal ulcer measuring raised borders, fluffy hyphae, finger-like projections, and minor hypopyon in the cornea is discovered during examination. What's the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 1. Aspergillosis.
Pain and watering in the eye for 36 hours with presence of corneal ulcer having elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger-like projections and minimal hypopyon is highly suggestive of fungal corneal ulcer. Among the options, Aspergillus is the only fungus. Fungal corneal ulcers are commonly caused due to injury by vegetative material. These ulcers have feathery borders. Along with this, satellite lesions, ciliary congestion and a Wessely immune ring can be seen around the ulcer.  


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 227.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions have a familial mode of inheritance ? 
(i) Retinoblastoma 
(ii) Retinitis pigmentosa 
(iii) Myopia 
(iv) Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. (i), (ii), (iii), (iv) .
Familial disease is a disease that runs in families, passed on from one generation to the next. All four diseases mentioned in the question(Retinoblastoma/Retinitis pigmentosa/Myopia/Primary open-angle glaucoma) have some form of familial inheritance and genetic predisposition. 


 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 38,40,236,237,296,297,314,315 .

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a 5-year history of primary open-angle glaucoma presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine follow-up. He has been compliant with his prescribed topical medications. On slit-lamp examination, the ophthalmologist notices dark pigmentation over the palpebral conjunctiva of both eyes. The patient denies any irritation, pain, or visual changes. Given this finding and his treatment history, the pigmentation is most likely associated with which of the following classes of medications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: 3. Epinephrine.
Adrenochrome deposits are common after chronic use of topical epinephrine for glaucoma. One classic cause is oxidation of epinephrine drops, which can lead to conjunctival deposits of adrenochrome, a melanin-like pigment accumulation. They appear as dark pigment on conjunctiva. 

Other options:
1. Prostaglandins- can cause heterochromia iridis but not black deposits. 
3. & 4. don't cause any pigmentation in the conjunctiva. 



Reference: Domarus D. Adrenochromeinlagerungen in die Kornea ("Schwarze Hornhaut"). Klinisch-pathologischer Fallbericht [Adrenochrome deposits in the cornea ("Black cornea"). A clinical-pathological case report]. Ophthalmologica. 1977;175(3):166-70. German. doi: 10.1159/000308650. PMID: 896145.
